commit_message:
Refactor rally plugin

This patch refactors rally plugin for senlin. Since the
plugin for basic cluster and profile operations has been
merged into rally repo, we can remove duplicated util
functions and test scenarios from senlin repo. Related
test jobs are also changed accordingly.

Change-Id: Ic8ac5acac17bd013c25089a7db58d32ac0dfa5ba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/63/351463/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from rally.plugins.openstack.scenarios.senlin import utils as senlin_utils class SenlinPlugin(senlin_utils.SenlinScenario): timeout=senlin_utils.CONF.benchmark.senlin_action_timeout)
deleted_lines: from rally.common import loggingfrom rally import exceptionsLOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) SENLIN_BENCHMARK_OPTS = [ cfg.FloatOpt("senlin_action_timeout", default=3600, help="Time in seconds to wait for senlin action to finish."), ] benchmark_group = cfg.OptGroup(name="benchmark", title="benchmark options") CONF.register_opts(SENLIN_BENCHMARK_OPTS, group=benchmark_group) class SenlinScenario(scenario.OpenStackScenario): @atomic.action_timer("senlin.list_clusters") def _list_clusters(self): """Return user cluster list.""" return list(self.admin_clients("senlin").clusters()) @atomic.action_timer("senlin.create_cluster") def _create_cluster(self, profile_id, desired_capacity=0, min_size=0, max_size=-1, timeout=None, metadata=None): """Create a new cluster from attributes. :param profile_id: ID of profile used to create cluster :param desired_capacity: The capacity or initial number of nodes owned by the cluster :param min_size: The minimum number of nodes owned by the cluster :param max_size: The maximum number of nodes owned by the cluster. -1 means no limit :param timeout: The timeout value in minutes for cluster creation :param metadata: A set of key value pairs to associate with the cluster :returns: object of cluster created. """ attrs = {} attrs["profile_id"] = profile_id attrs["name"] = self.generate_random_name() attrs["desired_capacity"] = desired_capacity attrs["min_size"] = min_size attrs["max_size"] = max_size attrs["metadata"] = metadata if timeout: attrs["timeout"] = timeout cluster = self.admin_clients("senlin").create_cluster(**attrs) cluster = utils.wait_for_status( cluster, ready_statuses=["ACTIVE"], failure_statuses=["ERROR"], update_resource=self._get_cluster, timeout=CONF.benchmark.senlin_action_timeout) return cluster @atomic.action_timer("senlin.get_cluster") def _get_cluster(self, cluster): """Get cluster details. :param cluster: cluster to get :returns: object of cluster """ try: return self.admin_clients("senlin").get_cluster(cluster.id) except Exception as e: if getattr(e, "code", getattr(e, "http_status", 400)) == 404: raise exceptions.GetResourceNotFound(resource=cluster.id) raise exceptions.GetResourceFailure(resource=cluster.id, err=e) timeout=CONF.benchmark.senlin_action_timeout) @atomic.action_timer("senlin.delete_cluster") def _delete_cluster(self, cluster): """Delete given cluster. Returns after the cluster is successfully deleted. :param cluster: cluster object to delete """ cluster = self.admin_clients("senlin").delete_cluster(cluster) utils.wait_for_status( cluster, # FIXME(Yanyan Hu): ready_statuses is actually useless # for deleting Senlin cluster since cluster db item will # be removed once cluster is deleted successfully. ready_statuses=["DELETED"], failure_statuses=["ERROR"], check_deletion=True, update_resource=self._get_cluster, timeout=CONF.benchmark.senlin_action_timeout) @atomic.action_timer("senlin.create_profile") def _create_profile(self, spec, metadata=None): """Create a new profile from attributes. :param spec: spec dictionary used to create profile :param metadata: A set of key value pairs to associate with the profile :returns: object of profile created """ attrs = {} attrs["spec"] = spec attrs["name"] = self.generate_random_name() if metadata: attrs["metadata"] = metadata return self.admin_clients("senlin").create_profile(**attrs) @atomic.action_timer("senlin.get_profile") def _get_profile(self, profile_id): """Get profile details. :param profile_id: ID of profile to get :returns: object of profile """ return self.admin_clients("senlin").get_profile(profile_id) @atomic.action_timer("senlin.delete_profile") def _delete_profile(self, profile): """Delete given profile. Returns after the profile is successfully deleted. :param profile: profile object to be deleted """ self.admin_clients("senlin").delete_profile(profile) @validation.required_openstack(admin=True) @validation.required_services(consts.Service.SENLIN) @scenario.configure(context={"cleanup": ["senlin"]}) def create_and_delete_profile_cluster(self, profile_spec, desired_capacity=0, min_size=0, max_size=-1, timeout=3600, metadata=None): """Create a profile and a cluster and then delete them. Measure the "senlin profile-create", "senlin profile-delete", "senlin cluster-create" and "senlin cluster-delete" commands performance. :param profile_spec: spec dictionary used to create profile :param desired_capacity: The capacity or initial number of nodes owned by the cluster :param min_size: The minimum number of nodes owned by the cluster :param max_size: The maximum number of nodes owned by the cluster. -1 means no limit :param timeout: The timeout value in seconds for cluster creation :param metadata: A set of key value pairs to associate with the cluster """ profile = self._create_profile(profile_spec) cluster = self._create_cluster(profile.id, desired_capacity, min_size, max_size, timeout, metadata) self._delete_cluster(cluster) self._delete_profile(profile)

commit_message:
Update the api-ref to mark the v2 API as deprecated

The v2 API was deprecated in mitaka with change:

e63a8311fa2e5d7cccdb76b4cd3fc17719cc86c6

The api-ref needs to be updated to show that as
well since that's the main thing someone sees when
they are in the API docs.

The status value comes from:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/VersionDiscovery#status

Change-Id: I6dc5d8fd26d0981e5d83e829fe2dd09b7b9b4c17

commit_message:
[ha-guide] De-emphasis networking and firewall configuration for databases

It is not this guide's role to replicate each distribution's networking
and security documentation.  Provide pointer and starting points but not
line by line instructions.

Change-Id: I6ddd05475d9cf54df9089c2889bca66bb24aa92e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/44/350944/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This can be achieved through the use of either the ``iptables`` command such as: --protocol tcp --match tcp --dport ${PORT} \ --source ${NODE-IP-ADDRESS} --jump ACCEPT Make sure to save the changes once you are done, this will vary depending on your distribution: - `Ubuntu <http://askubuntu.com/questions/66890/how-can-i-make-a-specific-set-of-iptables-rules-permanent#66905>`_ - `Fedora <https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/How_to_edit_iptables_rules>`_ Alternatively you may be able to make modifications using the ``firewall-cmd`` utility for FirewallD that is available on many Linux distributions:To configure SELinux to permit Galera Cluster to operate, you may need to use the ``semanage`` utility to open the ports it uses, for example: Older versions of some distributions, which do not have an up-to-date policy for securing Galera, may also require SELinux to be more relaxed about database access and actions:
deleted_lines: ``iptables`` ^^^^^^^^^^^^^ For many Linux distributions, you can configure the firewall using the ``iptables`` utility. To do so, complete the following steps: #. For each cluster node, run the following commands, replacing ``NODE-IP-ADDRESS`` with the IP address of the cluster node you want to open the firewall to: --protocol tcp --match tcp --dport 3306 \ --source NODE-IP-ADDRESS --jump ACCEPT # iptables --append INPUT --in-interface eth0 \ --protocol tcp --match tcp --dport 4567 \ --source NODE-IP-ADDRESS --jump ACCEPT # iptables --append INPUT --in-interface eth0 \ --protocol tcp --match tcp --dport 4568 \ --source NODE-IP-ADDRESS --jump ACCEPT # iptables --append INPUT --in-interface eth0 \ --protocol tcp --match tcp --dport 4444 \ --source NODE-IP-ADDRESS --jump ACCEPT In the event that you also want to configure multicast replication, run this command as well: .. code-block:: console # iptables --append INPUT --in-interface eth0 \ --protocol udp --match udp --dport 4567 \ --source NODE-IP-ADDRESS --jump ACCEPT #. Make the changes persistent. For servers that use ``init``, use the :command:`save` command: .. code-block:: console # service save iptables For servers that use ``systemd``, you need to save the current packet filtering to the path of the file that ``iptables`` reads when it starts. This path can vary by distribution, but common locations are in the ``/etc`` directory, such as: - ``/etc/sysconfig/iptables`` - ``/etc/iptables/iptables.rules`` When you find the correct path, run the :command:`iptables-save` command: .. code-block:: console # iptables-save > /etc/sysconfig/iptables With the firewall configuration saved, whenever your OpenStack database starts. ``firewall-cmd`` ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ For many Linux distributions, you can configure the firewall using the ``firewall-cmd`` utility for FirewallD. To do so, complete the following steps on each cluster node: #. Add the Galera Cluster service: .. code-block:: console # firewall-cmd --add-service=mysql #. For each instance of OpenStack database in your cluster, run the following commands, replacing ``NODE-IP-ADDRESS`` with the IP address of the cluster node you want to open the firewall to: .. code-block:: console # firewall-cmd --add-port=3306/tcp # firewall-cmd --add-port=4567/tcp # firewall-cmd --add-port=4568/tcp # firewall-cmd --add-port=4444/tcp In the event that you also want to configure multicast replication, run this command as well: .. code-block:: console # firewall-cmd --add-port=4567/udp #. To make this configuration persistent, repeat the above commands with the :option:`--permanent` option. # firewall-cmd --add-port=4567/tcp --permanent # firewall-cmd --add-port=4568/tcp --permanent # firewall-cmd --add-port=4444/tcp --permanent # firewall-cmd --add-port=4567/udp --permanent With the firewall configuration saved, whenever your OpenStack database starts.To configure SELinux to permit Galera Cluster to operate, complete the following steps on each cluster node: #. Using the ``semanage`` utility, open the relevant ports: # semanage port -a -t mysqld_port_t -p tcp 4567 # semanage port -a -t mysqld_port_t -p tcp 4568 # semanage port -a -t mysqld_port_t -p tcp 4444 In the event that you use multicast replication, you also need to open ``4567`` to UDP traffic: .. code-block:: console # semanage port -a -t mysqld_port_t -p udp 4567 #. Set SELinux to allow the database server to run:With these options set, SELinux now permits Galera Cluster to operate.

commit_message:
Set minimum required options

The oslo.config 3.10 version supports a required parameter to
indicate config options that require input. This patch sets various
options as required using the openstack install guide as guidance.

Change-Id: Id81bb91111e447be4cac3c33b8a3ef0ff00bb0ee

subject: Workaround for puppet-ceph zuul-cloning
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-03 19:38:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/commit/aaac0731aff6197f26fa4be08184cffd602cedd2', 'message': "Workaround for puppet-ceph zuul-cloning

We need to override ZUUL_BRANCH with a fake 'stable/mitaka' for Puppet

* test puppet-ceph/hammer with mitaka modules
* test puppet-ceph/master with newton and beyond modules

commit_message:
Workaround for puppet-ceph zuul-cloning

Currently, puppet-ceph stable/hammer CI tries to clone Puppet OpenStack
modules using stable/hammer branch but they don't have it, only
puppet-ceph does.
We need to override ZUUL_BRANCH with a fake 'stable/mitaka' for Puppet
OpenStack modules and then checkout 'stable/hammer' for puppet-ceph.

This workaround will allow us to:
* test puppet-ceph/hammer with mitaka modules
* test puppet-ceph/master with newton and beyond modules

Note: for our r10k users, no problem, they use git to checkout the right
branch, so they don't have the bug.

Change-Id: I004ee95e6bd97992aeebd08447396e3b8a29e09f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration refs/changes/60/350760/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Workaround for puppet-ceph, where we need to checkout # OpenStack modules from stable/mitaka when working on stable/hammer. # Ceph Hammer works with Mitaka and before. # Ceph Jewel works with Newton and beyond. if [[ "$ZUUL_BRANCH" == "stable/hammer" ]]; then ZUUL_BRANCH='stable/mitaka' PUPPET_CEPH_ZUUL_BRANCH='stable/hammer' fi # Clone openstack/puppet-ceph using the real ZUUL_BRANCH. if [ ! -z "$PUPPET_CEPH_ZUUL_BRANCH" ]; then /usr/zuul-env/bin/zuul-cloner -m clonemap.yaml \ --cache-dir /opt/git \ --zuul-ref $ZUUL_REF \ --zuul-branch $PUPPET_CEPH_ZUUL_BRANCH \ --zuul-url $ZUUL_URL \ git://git.openstack.org openstack/puppet-ceph fi

commit_message:
Fix the kolla_docker issue with docker 1.12

After docker 1.12, the RepoTags will be None rather than [] in the
image list API. This PS will handle the both case.

Change-Id: Ie2da44b44229c2f190550755b50876f607f9cc0c
Closes-Bug: #1608358

commit_message:
Bring dontaudit selinux rules to the foreground

There are selinux rules that are set to "dontaudit".
If there are AVCs, they won't show up, even with selinux set to
permissive.
These AVCs will cause things to fail if selinux is set to
enforcing (and still not print the AVC).

In this commit we disable the dontaudit rules [1] so that they are
printed properly in the audit log.
Note that there can and will be false positives (or things we
don't care about in the context of OpenStack).

[1]: http://red.ht/2ardPCl

Change-Id: Ifa25f20dbd11fb16281bda5dffd45f80675c9091

commit_message:
Change workers to be static when using kubernates

When orchestration engine is Kubernates,
ansible_processor_vcpus is not defined.

This patch changes workers to be static when using kubernates

commit_message:
Enable central logging without deploying elasticsearch/kibana

This changed introduces 4 new parameters to be able to use an existing
elasticsearch service for central logging.

* elasticsearch_address - address of elasticsearch server
* elasticsearch_protocol - protocol (HTTP/HTTPS) used by elasticsearch server
* enable_elasticsearch - deploy elasticsearch container
* enable_kibana - deploy kibana container

Closes-bug: #1584861

Change-Id: Ia1ff9ae8b6d9929c3826da02693d1e2fc9ea2522
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/12/320012/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Generate IV on HSM device for encrypt operations

FIPS 140-2 requires that the IV be generated by the HSM, on device.
This change makes the IV optional to the _build_gcm_mechanism
function and removes the generation of the random IV in the encrypt
method to defer the IV creation to the HSM.

Change-Id: I5ac3b8f67b7ece35a283e7468a4fc06592576996
Closes-Bug: 1606591
Co-Authored-By: Randall Burt <randall.burt@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/34/347434/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ck_mechanism = self._build_gcm_mechanism() ct_len = self.ffi.new("CK_ULONG *", pt_len + self.gcmtagsize * 2) # HSM-generated IVs are appended to the end of the ciphertext return { "iv": self.ffi.buffer(ct, ct_len[0])[-self.gcmtagsize:], "ct": self.ffi.buffer(ct, ct_len[0])[:-self.gcmtagsize] def _build_gcm_mechanism(self, iv=None): if iv: iv_len = len(iv) gcm.pIv = iv gcm.ulIvLen = iv_len gcm.ulIvBits = iv_len * 8
deleted_lines: iv = self._generate_random(self.noncesize, session) ck_mechanism = self._build_gcm_mechanism(iv) ct_len = self.ffi.new("CK_ULONG *", pt_len + self.gcmtagsize) return { "iv": self.ffi.buffer(iv)[:], "ct": self.ffi.buffer(ct, ct_len[0])[:] def _build_gcm_mechanism(self, iv): iv_len = len(iv) gcm.pIv = iv gcm.ulIvLen = iv_len gcm.ulIvBits = iv_len * 8

commit_message:
Fix selective repo_build for aodh[mysql] requirement

The requirement aodh[mysql] is not properly interpreted by the
requirements template, and thus causes a build failure.

This patch ensures that this requirement is included in the
test process, and that it is interpreted properly and builds.

Change-Id: Ia17ee7788f3218db0c7ece95d3e11aa900f7fd98
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_build refs/changes/22/351322/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

assert_ping() was changed recently to be async-friendly, but
the change caused the drop of a single packet to throw an
error.  Since occasionally the first packet is lost due to
address resolution (ARP) we can't use it for checking liveness
of an IP.

Restored assert_ping() and moved updated code to
assert_async_ping() since that is a special-case.

(cherry picked from commit ca2aa3ca05aafcd3b7a81b81f8280ed363009f11)

commit_message:
Restore old assert_ping behavior

assert_ping() was changed recently to be async-friendly, but
the change caused the drop of a single packet to throw an
error.  Since occasionally the first packet is lost due to
address resolution (ARP) we can't use it for checking liveness
of an IP.

Restored assert_ping() and moved updated code to
assert_async_ping() since that is a special-case.

(cherry picked from commit ca2aa3ca05aafcd3b7a81b81f8280ed363009f11)
Change-Id: Ibe69417a0d819d4cd87e2f487c08fd126b1024e2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/04/351404/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def assert_ping(src_namespace, dst_ip, timeout=1, count=1): ipversion = netaddr.IPAddress(dst_ip).version ping_command = 'ping' if ipversion == 4 else 'ping6' ns_ip_wrapper = ip_lib.IPWrapper(src_namespace) ns_ip_wrapper.netns.execute([ping_command, '-c', count, '-W', timeout, dst_ip]) def assert_async_ping(src_namespace, dst_ip, timeout=1, count=1, interval=1): fs = [executor.submit(assert_async_ping, namespace, ip, count=10)
deleted_lines: def assert_ping(src_namespace, dst_ip, timeout=1, count=1, interval=1): fs = [executor.submit(assert_ping, namespace, ip, count=10)

commit_message:
Restore old assert_ping behavior

assert_ping() was changed recently to be async-friendly, but
the change caused the drop of a single packet to throw an
error.  Since occasionally the first packet is lost due to
address resolution (ARP) we can't use it for checking liveness
of an IP.

Restored assert_ping() and moved updated code to
assert_async_ping() since that is a special-case.

(cherry picked from commit ca2aa3ca05aafcd3b7a81b81f8280ed363009f11)
Change-Id: Ibe69417a0d819d4cd87e2f487c08fd126b1024e2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/03/351403/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def assert_ping(src_namespace, dst_ip, timeout=1, count=1): ipversion = netaddr.IPAddress(dst_ip).version ping_command = 'ping' if ipversion == 4 else 'ping6' ns_ip_wrapper = ip_lib.IPWrapper(src_namespace) ns_ip_wrapper.netns.execute([ping_command, '-c', count, '-W', timeout, dst_ip]) def assert_async_ping(src_namespace, dst_ip, timeout=1, count=1, interval=1): fs = [executor.submit(assert_async_ping, namespace, ip, count=10)
deleted_lines: def assert_ping(src_namespace, dst_ip, timeout=1, count=1, interval=1): fs = [executor.submit(assert_ping, namespace, ip, count=10)

commit_message:
Backport py_pkgs changes from Newton

A minimal backport of the Newton changes to the py_pkgs lookup
plugin in order to support https://review.openstack.org/350576
does not appear to be possible.

This is therefore a complete backport of all changes.

Related-Bug: #1605846
Related-Bug: #1609056
Needed-By: If52d073d43081468e2faf2cd063c4b211c29994f

commit_message:
Delete execute permission of two files

This two files were given execution permission
by mistake. This patch removes the error permission.

Change-Id: Iba2f54ab1fd7ec36011dc1873322859322d6c001

commit_message:
Update the home-page info with the developer documentation

Since there are so many components in openstack,
by describing the URL info in the configuration file,
it is more convenient to find the developer documentation
than from the unified portal

Change-Id: I511908010e339a84479b342af84aeb5504f4e6ce

commit_message:
Resource Browser links now respect webroot

Use '/' in routeProvider.when()...but no leading slash when generating links.

Closes-Bug: #1607882
Change-Id: I04670ddb58873a5976f1c9a1d1137823e40b8266

commit_message:
Update assertRaises() to assertRaisesRegexp()

There are many places in the tests where we use assertRaises() which is
not recommended. The recommended one is assertRaisesRegexp(). Change
the assertRaises() call to assertRaisesRegexp().

more information:https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/unittest.html#unittest.TestCase.debug

Closes-Bug #1525909

Change-Id: I378b35d465a6e65fbeb00e44b32a866311adc6a9

Implements: blueprint tripleo-ovs-dpdk
Depends-On: I79308ac5949a47a707d42bb2566407b9e8adfb9c

Change-Id: I46331a882eca97d8b2ea0229ff768ce629971a6d
'}]
commit_message:
Add DPDK driver modprobe for loading modules on reboot

driverctl will be used to bind the pci with the DPDK driver,
but the DPDK driver modules has to be loaded for it. Adding
sysconfig modules files to load driver module on reboot.

Implements: blueprint tripleo-ovs-dpdk
Depends-On: I79308ac5949a47a707d42bb2566407b9e8adfb9c

Change-Id: I46331a882eca97d8b2ea0229ff768ce629971a6d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-vswitch refs/changes/64/347464/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: file { 'dpdk-driver-module-loader': ensure => file, path => '/etc/sysconfig/modules/dpdk-driver.modules', mode => '0700', content => template('vswitch/dpdk-driver.modules.erb'), }

commit_message:
Add monasca api read-only user role

This will allow dashboard/operator users to see but not add data.

Change-Id: I16a2329356cc9e7d03d2f3e1394127006d6e487e
Implements: blueprint read-only-api-user

commit_message:
resource-providers: Populate allocation fields

Populates the allocations table in the API database with usage
information by calling the new placement API from the Nova resource
tracker.

Change-Id: Ia90ddb7d148f5ec9cb67cf378b93784371af82c7
blueprint: resource-providers-allocations
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/77/300177/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================ Resource Providers - Allocations ================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/resource-providers-allocations This blueprint specification explains the process of migrating the data that stores allocated/assigned resource amounts from the older schema to the new schema introduced in the `resource-providers` spec. Problem description =================== The `compute-node-inventory-newton` specification pulls capacity data fields for resource types out of the `compute_nodes` table and places that information into the `inventories` table, with one row in the table per resource class and resource provider. This was necessary in order to properly handle resources that are not local to a particular compute node but rather shared between many nodes. We need to similarly migrate resource amount fields in the `instance_extra` table that store information about the amount of different types of resources that are assigned to consumers of those resources. Use Cases --------- As a deployer that has chosen to use a shared storage solution for storing instance ephemeral disks, I want Nova and Horizon to report the correct usage and capacity information. Proposed change =============== The two major components of this spec are the alignment of the underlying database schema and the changes needed to the `nova.objects.ComputeNode` object model to read and write resource allocation information from the `allocations` table instead of the `compute_nodes` and `instance_extra` tables. Alignment of database schema ---------------------------- To align the underlying database storage for inventory records, we propose to move the resource usage and capacity fields from their current locations in the database to the new `allocations` table added in the `resource-providers` blueprint. Currently, the Nova database stores allocation records for the following resource classes: * vCPUs: * `compute_nodes.vcpus_used`: Number of vCPUs allocated to virtual machines running on that compute node. After this blueprint is implemented, this field will be deprecated and its value will be considered untrusted * `instances.vcpus`: Number of vCPUs taken by the instance. This field *should* be considered deprecated and its value untrusted * `instance_extra.flavor.current.vcpus`: Number of vCPUs consumed by this instance at the current time * RAM: * `compute_nodes.memory_mb_used`: Amount of RAM allocated to virtual machines running on that compute node. After this blueprint is implemented, this field will be deprecated and its value will be considered untrusted * `compute_nodes.free_ram_mb`: A calculated field that can go away since its value can be determined by looking at used versus capacity values * `instances.memory_mb`: Amount of RAM taken by the instance. This field *should* be considered deprecated and its value untrusted * `instance_extra.flavor.current.memory_mb`: Amount of RAM consumed by this instance at the current time * Disk: * `compute_nodes.local_gb_used`: Amount of disk storage allocated for ephemeral disks of virtual machines running on the compute node. After this blueprint is implemented, this field will be deprecated and its value will be considered untrusted * `compute_nodes.free_disk_gb`: A calculated field that can go away since its value can be determined by looking at used versus capacity values * `instances.root_gb`: Amount of local disk space allocated for the root disk by the instance. This field *should* be considered deprecated and its value untrusted * `instances.ephemeral_gb`: Amount of local disk space allocated for ephemeral disk by the instance. This field *should* be considered deprecated and its value untrusted * `instance_extra.flavor.current.root_gb`: Amount of local disk for the root disk consumed by this instance at the current time * `instance_extra.flavor.current.ephemeral_gb`: Amount of local disk for ephemeral disk consumed by this instance at the current time * `instance_extra.flavor.current.swap`: Amount of local disk (in GB) for swap space consumed by this instance at the current time * PCI devices: * `pci_stats`: Stores summary information about device "pools" (per product_id and vendor_id combination). This information is made redundant by the `pci-generate-stats` blueprint, which generates a summary view of pool information for PCI devices from the main record table, `pci_devices` table * `pci_devices` table stores all the individual PCI device records, including the status of the device and which instance (if any) the device has been assigned to. * NUMA topologies: * `compute_nodes.numa_topology`: Serialized `nova.objects.numa.NUMATopology` object that represents both the compute node's NUMA topology **and the assigned NUMA topologies for instances on the compute node**. * `instance_extra.numa_topology`: Serialized `nova.objects.instance_numa_topology.InstanceNUMATopology` object for the NUMA cells consumed by the instance To recap from the `resource-providers` spec, the `allocations` table schema looks like so:: CREATE TABLE allocations ( id INT UNSIGNED NOT NULL AUTOINCREMENT PRIMARY KEY, resource_provider_id INT UNSIGNED NOT NULL, consumer_id VARCHAR(64) NOT NULL, resource_class_id INT UNSIGNED NOT NULL, used INT UNSIGNED NOT NULL, INDEX (resource_provider_id, resource_class_id), INDEX (consumer_id), INDEX (resource_class_id) ); The `allocations` table is designed to answer the following questions: * What quantity of resource X has been consumed on provider Y? * Which consumers have had what amounts of resource X allocated to them on provider Y? .. note:: It is important to point out that the `allocations` table is specifically NOT designed to answer the question "which unit of some resource is assigned/placed/pinned to a particular consumer?". Put more bluntly, the `allocations` table will tell you which instances are consuming vCPUs on a compute node, but won't tell you which instance is pinned to which CPU on a compute node. Likewise, the `allocations` table isn't intended to tell you what fraction of disk resources is swap, what is ephemeral and what is used for root disks. Disk resources are disk resources. Fields like `swap_gb` will stay in the `instance_extra.flavor` blob for now. In online object migrations, we will transform fields in the `compute_nodes` and `instance_extra` tables that store resource allocation amounts to instead be rows the `allocations` table. A method on the `nova.object.ComputeNode` object called `_migrate_allocations()` will be introduced that will be triggered when the object code detects an unmigrated compute node object. Specifically, the following data migrations will be performed in `_migrate_allocations()`.The `_migrate_allocations()` method should be a `@remotable` method that uses a single database transaction to ensure all DB writes are done atomically. 1) Grab the list of instances that are active on the compute node. 2) For each instance, grab the `nova.objects.Flavor` object representing the **current** instance type that the instance is consuming on the host. 3) Insert one record each for RAM and vCPUs into the `allocations` table. Use the flavor's `memory_mb` and `vcpus` field values. The `consumer_id` field value shall be the instance's `uuid` field value. The `resource_provider_id` field value shall be the compute node's `uuid` field value. The `resource_class_id` field shall contain the identifier for the appropriate resource class (either RAM or vCPU) 4) Insert **one** record for the DISK resource class. The amount used should be the sum of the `root_gb`, `ephemeral_gb`, and `swap` field values of the flavor. The `resource_provider_id` value of the record shall be the compute node's resource provider ID *or* the generic resource pool's provider ID if the compute node is associated to an aggregate that is tied to a resource pool 5) If the `instance_extra.numa_topology` is not None, insert one record in the `allocations` table for the `NUMA_SOCKETS`, `NUMA_CORES`, and `NUMA_THREADS` resource classes, summing the `sockets`, `threads` and `cores` field values of the `numa_topology.cells[0..n].virt_cpu_topology` object fields. Insert one record for the `NUMA_MEMORY` resource class by summing the `numa_topology.cells[0..n].memory` field value for each NUMA cell in the topology. .. note:: Again, the `allocations` table is **not** answering placement or pinning questions like "which NUMA node is this instance pinned to?" Instead, the `allocations` table is only answering questions about how many sockets (NUMA cells), cores, and threads an instance is consuming. 6) If the `pci_devices` table contains any records linking the instance UUID to any PCI device in `ALLOCATED` status, insert one record in the `allocations` table for **each type of PCI device**. The `used` column should be the total number of devices. Changes to `ComputeNode` object model ------------------------------------- In order to ease the transition from the old-style mechanism for determining allocation information, we propose modifying the `nova.objects.ComputeNode` object in following ways: 1) Make the existing `vcpus_used`, `memory_mb_used`, and `local_gb_used` fields be read using a single query against the `allocations` table and populate the values of the object fields so that the user is none the wiser that the storage mechanism has changed behind the scenes. A single SQL query may be used to grab the above fields:: SELECT resource_class_id, SUM(used) as used FROM allocations WHERE resource_provider_id = $COMPUTE_NODE_UUID; 2) Code that *writes* allocation field changes is entirely in the `nova.objects.Instance` object's `save()` method. Where code that currently writes a serialized `nova.objects.Flavor` to the `instance_extra.flavor` field, we will want to *also* write records to the `allocations` table for the various resource classes consumed by the instance. We won't change the fact that the `Flavor` object is stored in the `instance_extra.flavor` field in this blueprint, since that field is used extensively in the migrate instance processes. 3) Code that *reads* resource allocation amounts for each `nova.objects.Instance` object should be changed to read from `allocations` instead of either `instances` or `instance_extra`. Alternatives ------------ We could continue to store allocated resource amounts in the variety of field storage formats that we currently do. However, adding new resource classes/types will almost inevitably result in yet another field being added to the database schema and a whole new way of accounting hacked into Nova. Data model impact ----------------- No new tables, new fields or changed fields in the database. Transparent (to the caller) changes in the object models. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- We should add an execution piece to the `nova-manage db online_migrations` command that can batch-process the allocation data migrations. Developer impact ---------------- None. Calling interfaces for `ComputeNode` and `Instance` objects stay the same. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: cdent Other contributors: jaypipes Work Items ---------- The following distinct tasks are involved in this spec's implementation: * Add a `nova.objects.ComputeNode._migrate_allocations()` method to migrate the allocations fields from `compute_nodes` and `instance_extra` to `allocations` * Modify `nova.objects.ComputeNode` model to read allocation information from the `allocations` table instead of the `compute_nodes` table * Modify `nova.objects.Instance` model to store consumed resource information for all resource classes to the `allocations` table instead of the `instance_extra` table, and read the resource allocation information from the `allocations` table instead of the `instance_extra` table * Full functional integration tests added which stress the migration paths and ensure backwards compatibility Dependencies ============ * `resource-classes` blueprint must be completed before this one. * `resource-providers` blueprint must be completed before this one. * `compute-node-inventory-newton` blueprint must be completed before this one because it ensures each compute node is added as a resource provider with a UUID. Testing ======= Full unit and functional integration tests must be added that demonstrate the migration of allocation-related fields is done appropriately and in a backwards-compatible way. Documentation Impact ==================== Developer docs should be added that detail the new `allocations` table and object models. References ========== [1] Bugs related to resource usage reporting and calculation: * Hypervisor summary shows incorrect total storage (Ceph) https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1387812 * rbd backend reports wrong 'local_gb_used' for compute node https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1493760 * nova hypervisor-stats shows wrong disk usage with shared storage https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1414432 * report disk consumption incorrect in nova-compute https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1315988 * VMWare: available disk spaces(hypervisor-list) only based on a single datastore instead of all available datastores from cluster https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1347039 History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Disable stderr logging

OSLO logging currently defaults the 'use_stderr' option to True
which results duplicate logs in service daemon logs for both
upstart and systemd. To correct this issue the use_stderr
option has been set to false.

Change-Id: I1eabe119b362f544d75da35600ecb88fec1b829c
Closes-Bug: 1588051
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_zaqar refs/changes/17/351317/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Disable stderr logging use_stderr = False # Disable stderr logging use_stderr = False

commit_message:
Add channel #openstack-dib for diskimage-builder

It would be beneficial for the diskimage-builder project to have its own
IRC channel to focus efforts and have discussions on development. This
commit adds it to accessbot and gerritbot channel lists.

Change-Id: I9654843252859362c94a899c04274507cab1ff1d

commit_message:
Correct the command in cluster doc

Following the tutorial, I found these command is invalid
openstack cluster shrink and openstack expand.
According to the description, I think it means
openstack cluster scale in and openstack cluster scale out.

Change-Id: Ibb38e0d3422c7d6f44b4b85cf26f93fb8e1d3027
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/03/351103/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ``openstack cluster scale in`` and ``openstack cluster scale out``The :command:`openstack cluster scale in` command and the :command:`openstack cluster scale out` command are provided for convenience when $ openstack cluster scale out --count 2 web_servers $ openstack cluster scale in --count 2 web_servers
deleted_lines: ``openstack cluster shrink`` and ``openstack cluster expand``The :command:`openstack cluster shrink` command and the :command:`openstack cluster expand` command are provided for convenience when $ openstack cluster expand --count 2 web_servers $ openstack cluster shrink --count 2 web_servers

commit_message:
Update the 'list' method of volumeprovider about Cinder

'fuxi' in search_opts should be extracted from CONF:
Otherwise, CONF.volume_from changed, cmd docker volume ls could not obtain the expected result.

Change-Id: Ieb5ba432110a371ae175940d9b9ee63bc3ef2ea4
Closes-Bug: #1609763
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuxi refs/changes/43/351143/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: search_opts = {'metadata': {consts.VOLUME_FROM: CONF.volume_from}}

subject: Migrate to using keystoneauth Sessions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-19 13:41:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/dbd395d9663c80a76c87fb8a969f001732c7b78d', 'message': "Migrate to using keystoneclient Sessions

We currently construct keystone client objects directly, which
is no longer the preferred way.  Instead, we should be using Sessions
which allows use of different auth plugins.  This change attempts to
migrate our keystone usage to this model.

Additionally, we currently rely on the imported keystonemiddleware
auth_token's configuration for all of the keystone credentials used
by the ironic service user.  This is bad, as that config is internal
to that library and may change at any time.  Also, the service user
may be using different credentials than the token validator.

This refactors the keystone module to use Sessions and centralizes
all keystone credential configuration there.  It attempts to provide
some backward compat for users who have not yet updated their config,
by falling back to the authtoken config section when required.

Change-Id: I166eebefc1e1335a1a7b632149cf6441512e9d5e
Closes-bug: #1418341
Co-Authored-By: Adam Gandelman <adamg@ubuntu.com>
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-10-19 14:37:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/6d4e2f78358a701591c54a5077812b99f86b5388', 'message': "Migrate to using keystoneclient Sessions

Related-Bug: #1418341
Co-Authored-By: Adam Gandelman <adamg@ubuntu.com>
"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2015-11-11 13:03:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/6ef872f5ec95d28dbc2fc0529c3c37dab116cfc1', 'message': "Migrate to using keystoneclient Sessions

We currently construct keystone client objects directly, which
is no longer the preferred way.  Instead, we should be using Sessions
which allows use of different auth plugins.  This change attempts to
migrate our keystone usage to this model.

Additionally, we currently rely on the imported keystonemiddleware
auth_token's configuration for all of the keystone credentials used
by the ironic service user.  This is bad, as that config is internal
to that library and may change at any time.  Also, the service user
may be using different credentials than the token validator.

This refactors the keystone module to use Sessions and centralizes
all keystone credential configuration there.  It attempts to provide
some backward compat for users who have not yet updated their config,
by falling back to the authtoken config section when required.

Implementation details:

- Only password auth plugin is supported for now in config.

- Sessions constructed from request token are always created fresh.

- Session constructed from auth plugin defined in config is global and is
  created only once on first attempt to create such session.

- The Keystone API version to work with is not specified in
  config/endpoints and is also discovered at first attempt to use a session,
  with preference given to Keystone API v3 if both v2 and v3 are available.
  Thus in a situation when in a running setup the Keystone service
  is completely switched over to other API version
  (e.g. from v2 to v3 with no v2 left) a restart of ironic-conductor service
  will be required to resolve the new configuration.

Change-Id: I166eebefc1e1335a1a7b632149cf6441512e9d5e
Closes-bug: #1422632
Related-Bug: #1418341
Co-Authored-By: Adam Gandelman <adamg@ubuntu.com>
"}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2015-11-27 11:38:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/1cbfca867c28f1ec65a37add1978e8b95117ab77', 'message': "Migrate to using keystoneauth Sessions

We currently construct Keystone client objects directly, which
is no longer the preferred way.  Instead, we should be using Sessions
which allows use of different auth plugins.  This change attempts to
migrate our Keystone usage to this model.

Additionally, we currently rely on the imported keystonemiddleware
auth_token's configuration for all of the Keystone credentials used
by the Ironic service user.  This is bad, as that config is internal
to that library and may change at any time.  Also, the service user
may be using different credentials than the token validator.

This refactors the keystone module to use Sessions and centralizes
all Keystone credential configuration there.  It attempts to provide
some backward compat for users who have not yet updated their config,
by falling back to the authtoken config section when required.

Operators impact:

- Session-related options (mostly concerning SSL configuration) should be
  moved to the already present [keystone] config section.

- New [keystone_auth] config section is added that specifies the
  Keystone auth plugin to use together with its required options.
  Note that the options there are dynamically registered and loaded
  by the specified plugin.

Implementetion details:

- using keystoneauth1 library instead of keystoneclient

- Session constructed from the auth plugin configured in [keystone_auth]
  section is created only once on first attempt to create such session
  and is reused afterwards.

Change-Id: I166eebefc1e1335a1a7b632149cf6441512e9d5e
Closes-bug: #1422632
Related-Bug: #1418341
Co-Authored-By: Adam Gandelman <adamg@ubuntu.com>
"}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2015-11-27 15:04:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/36808b5c526be0a3b2cbeb8ab19ab9a4d2eebcf9', 'message': "Migrate to using keystoneauth Sessions

We currently construct Keystone client objects directly, which
is no longer the preferred way.  Instead, we should be using Sessions
which allows use of different auth plugins.  This change attempts to
migrate our Keystone usage to this model.

Additionally, we currently rely on the imported keystonemiddleware
auth_token's configuration for all of the Keystone credentials used
by the Ironic service user.  This is bad, as that config is internal
to that library and may change at any time.  Also, the service user
may be using different credentials than the token validator.

This refactors the keystone module to use Sessions and centralizes
all Keystone credential configuration there.  It attempts to provide
some backward compat for users who have not yet updated their config,
by falling back to the authtoken config section when required.

Operators impact:

- Session-related options (mostly concerning SSL configuration) should be
  moved to the already present [keystone] config section.

- New [keystone_auth] config section is added that specifies the
  Keystone auth plugin to use together with its required options.
  Note that the options there are dynamically registered and loaded
  by the specified plugin.

Implementetion details:

- using keystoneauth1 library instead of keystoneclient

- Session constructed from the auth plugin configured in [keystone_auth]
  section is created only once on first attempt to create such session
  and is reused afterwards.

Change-Id: I166eebefc1e1335a1a7b632149cf6441512e9d5e
Closes-bug: #1422632
Related-Bug: #1418341
Co-Authored-By: Adam Gandelman <adamg@ubuntu.com>

"}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2015-11-30 19:34:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/ba10722ae9ecafbe17196b18bf09e40bb4a1dfff', 'message': "Migrate to using keystoneauth Sessions

We currently construct Keystone client objects directly, which
is no longer the preferred way.  Instead, we should be using Sessions
which allows use of different auth plugins.  This change attempts to
migrate our Keystone usage to this model.

Additionally, we currently rely on the imported keystonemiddleware
auth_token's configuration for all of the Keystone credentials used
by the Ironic service user.  This is bad, as that config is internal
to that library and may change at any time.  Also, the service user
may be using different credentials than the token validator.

This refactors the keystone module to use Sessions and centralizes
all Keystone credential configuration there.  It attempts to provide
some backward compat for users who have not yet updated their config,
by falling back to the authtoken config section when required.

Operators impact:

- Session-related options (mostly concerning SSL configuration) should be
  moved to the already present [keystone] config section.

- New [keystone_auth] config section is added that specifies the
  Keystone auth plugin to use together with its required options.
  Note that the options there are dynamically registered and loaded
  by the specified plugin.

Implementetion details:

- using keystoneauth1 library instead of keystoneclient

- Session constructed from the auth plugin configured in [keystone_auth]
  section is created only once on first attempt to create such session
  and is reused afterwards. This means that only auth plugins that can

"}, {'number': 23, 'created': '2016-02-23 09:52:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/95326c1ced7d10f4e5ad868d658c0b7d09cbd5d8', 'message': "Migrate to using keystoneauth Sessions

We currently construct Keystone client objects directly, which
is no longer the preferred way.  Instead, we should be using Sessions
which allows use of different auth plugins.  This change attempts to
migrate our Keystone usage to this model.

Additionally, we currently rely on the imported keystonemiddleware
auth_token's configuration for all of the Keystone credentials used
by the Ironic service user.  This is bad, as that config is internal
to that library and may change at any time.  Also, the service user
may be using different credentials than the token validator.

This refactors the keystone module to use Sessions and centralizes
all Keystone credential configuration there.  It attempts to provide
some backward compat for users who have not yet updated their config,
by falling back to the authtoken config section when required.

Operators impact:

- Session-related options (mostly concerning SSL configuration) should be
  moved to the already present [keystone] config section.

- New [keystone_auth] config section is added that specifies the
  Keystone auth plugin to use together with its required options.
  Note that the options there are dynamically registered and loaded
  by the specified plugin.

Implementetion details:

- using keystoneauth1 library instead of keystoneclient

- Session constructed from the auth plugin configured in [keystone_auth]
  section is created only once on first attempt to create such session
  and is reused afterwards. This means that only auth plugins that can
  re-authentificate themselves can be used (so no *Token plugins).

- DevStack plugin is configured to set the correct options

Change-Id: I166eebefc1e1335a1a7b632149cf6441512e9d5e
Closes-Bug: #1422632
Related-Bug: #1418341
Related-Bug: #1494776
Co-Authored-By: Adam Gandelman <adamg@ubuntu.com>

"}, {'number': 26, 'created': '2016-03-24 18:55:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/5e994f1b339cd5615e3b59bd549724c66d0438db', 'message': "Migrate to using keystoneauth Sessions

We currently construct Keystone client objects directly, which
is no longer the preferred way.  Instead, we should be using Sessions
which allows use of different auth plugins.  This change attempts to
migrate our Keystone usage to this model.

Additionally, we currently rely on the imported keystonemiddleware
auth_token's configuration for all of the Keystone credentials used
by the Ironic service user.  This is bad, as that config is internal
to that library and may change at any time.  Also, the service user
may be using different credentials than the token validator.

This refactors the keystone module to use Sessions and centralizes
all Keystone credential configuration there.  It attempts to provide
some backward compat for users who have not yet updated their config,
by falling back to the authtoken config section when required.

Operators impact:

- Authentification parameters for each service now should specified in
  the corresponding config section for this service ([glance], [neutron]
  etc). This includes providing both Keystone session-related options
  (timeout, SSL-related ones) and authentification options
  (`auth_type`, `auth_url` and proper options for the auth plugin).

- If loading from the service config section fails, an attempt is made
  to use respective options from [keystone_authtoken] section as a
  fall-back for backward compatibility.

Implementetion details:

- using keystoneauth1 library instead of keystoneclient

- For each service the keystone session is created only once and is
  reused further. This lowers the number of authentification requests
  made to Keystone but implies that only auth plugins that can
  re-authentificate themselves can be used (so no *Token plugins).

DevStack plugin is not updated in this very patch yet to test the
backward compatibility with old config options. It will be modified in a
subsequent patch.

Change-Id: I166eebefc1e1335a1a7b632149cf6441512e9d5e
Closes-Bug: #1422632
Related-Bug: #1418341
Related-Bug: #1494776
Co-Authored-By: Adam Gandelman <adamg@ubuntu.com>

"}, {'number': 36, 'created': '2016-06-13 12:56:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/bba1f88220de20f54e3dd2953f60a733fa3e8582', 'message': "Migrate to using keystoneauth Sessions

We currently construct Keystone client objects directly, which
is no longer the preferred way.  Instead, we should be using Sessions
which allows use of different auth plugins.  This change attempts to
migrate our Keystone usage to this model.

Additionally, we currently rely on the imported keystonemiddleware
auth_token's configuration for all of the Keystone credentials used
by the Ironic service user.  This is bad, as that config is internal
to that library and may change at any time.  Also, the service user
may be using different credentials than the token validator.

This refactors the keystone module to use Sessions and centralizes
all Keystone credential configuration there.  It attempts to provide
some backward compat for users who have not yet updated their config,
by falling back to the authtoken config section when required.

Operators impact:

- Authentification parameters for each service now should specified in
  the corresponding config section for this service ([glance], [neutron]
  etc). This includes providing both Keystone session-related options
  (timeout, SSL-related ones) and authentification options
  (`auth_type`, `auth_url` and proper options for the auth plugin).

- If loading from the service config section fails, an attempt is made
  to use respective options from [keystone_authtoken] section as a
  fall-back for backward compatibility.

Implementetion details:

- using keystoneauth1 library instead of keystoneclient

- For each service the keystone session is created only once and is
  reused further. This lowers the number of authentification requests
  made to Keystone but implies that only auth plugins that can
  re-authentificate themselves can be used (so no *Token plugins).

DevStack plugin is not updated in this very patch yet to test the
backward compatibility with old config options. It will be modified in a
subsequent patch.

Change-Id: I166eebefc1e1335a1a7b632149cf6441512e9d5e
Closes-Bug: #1422632
Related-Bug: #1418341
Related-Bug: #1494776
Co-Authored-By: Adam Gandelman <adamg@ubuntu.com>

"}, {'number': 49, 'created': '2016-08-02 15:28:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/021d4b919f1c0cefd29798f98c832caf26e7fc32', 'message': "Migrate to using keystoneauth Sessions

We currently construct Keystone client objects directly, which
is no longer the preferred way.  Instead, we should be using Sessions
which allows use of different auth plugins.  This change attempts to
migrate our Keystone usage to this model.

Additionally, we currently rely on the imported keystonemiddleware
auth_token's configuration for all of the Keystone credentials used
by the Ironic service user.  This is bad, as that config is internal
to that library and may change at any time.  Also, the service user
may be using different credentials than the token validator.

This refactors the keystone module to use Sessions.
It attempts to provide some backward compat for users
who have not yet updated their config,
by falling back to the authtoken config section when required.

Operators impact:

- Authentification parameters for each service now should specified in
  the corresponding config section for this service ([glance], [neutron]
  [swift], [inspector]).
  This includes providing both Keystone session-related options
  (timeout, SSL-related ones) and authentification options
  (`auth_type`, `auth_url` and proper options for the auth plugin).

- New config section `service_catalog` for Ironic service user
  credentials, used to resolve Ironic API URL from Keystone catalog.

- If loading from the service config section fails, an attempt is made
  to use respective options from [keystone_authtoken] section as a
  fall-back for backward compatibility.

Implementation details:

- using keystoneauth1 library instead of keystoneclient

- For each service the keystone session is created only once and is
  reused further. This lowers the number of authentification requests
  made to Keystone but implies that only auth plugins that can
  re-authentificate themselves can be used (so no *Token plugins).

This patch does not update the DevStack plugin, in order to test
backwards compatibility with old config options.
DevStack plugin will be modified in a subsequent patch.

Change-Id: I166eebefc1e1335a1a7b632149cf6441512e9d5e
Closes-Bug: #1422632

Related-Bug: #1494776

commit_message:
Migrate to using keystoneauth Sessions

We currently construct Keystone client objects directly, which
is no longer the preferred way.  Instead, we should be using Sessions
which allows use of different auth plugins.  This change attempts to
migrate our Keystone usage to this model.

Additionally, we currently rely on the imported keystonemiddleware
auth_token's configuration for all of the Keystone credentials used
by the Ironic service user.  This is bad, as that config is internal
to that library and may change at any time.  Also, the service user
may be using different credentials than the token validator.

This refactors the keystone module to use Sessions.
It attempts to provide some backward compat for users
who have not yet updated their config,
by falling back to the authtoken config section when required.

Operators impact:

- Authentification parameters for each service now should specified in
  the corresponding config section for this service ([glance], [neutron]
  [swift], [inspector]).
  This includes providing both Keystone session-related options
  (timeout, SSL-related ones) and authentification options
  (`auth_type`, `auth_url` and proper options for the auth plugin).

- New config section `service_catalog` for Ironic service user
  credentials, used to resolve Ironic API URL from Keystone catalog.

- If loading from the service config section fails, an attempt is made
  to use respective options from [keystone_authtoken] section as a
  fall-back for backward compatibility.

Implementation details:

- using keystoneauth1 library instead of keystoneclient

- For each service the keystone session is created only once and is
  reused further. This lowers the number of authentification requests
  made to Keystone but implies that only auth plugins that can
  re-authentificate themselves can be used (so no *Token plugins).

This patch does not update the DevStack plugin, in order to test
backwards compatibility with old config options.
DevStack plugin will be modified in a subsequent patch.

Change-Id: I166eebefc1e1335a1a7b632149cf6441512e9d5e
Closes-Bug: #1422632
Related-Bug: #1418341
Related-Bug: #1494776
Co-Authored-By: Adam Gandelman <adamg@ubuntu.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/82/236982/39 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ks = keystone.KeystoneSession() task.context.auth_token = ks.get_admin_auth_token()

commit_message:
VNF scaling: Infra (heat) driver update

implements blueprint: #vnf-scaling

All the VDUs are considered as one scale group irrespective
of list of VDUs specified in the scaling policy targets.
This will be addressed in follow-up patches.

Change-Id: I21bc0519860bc46f08363dd07333f29316e50bbd

commit_message:
Update the home-page info with the developer documentation

Since there are so many components in openstack,
by describing the URL info in the configuration file,
it is more convenient to find the developer documentation
than from the unified portal.

Change-Id: I158384a42ca39e39c0a2db7b437ccc25742bff8f

subject: Fix bug that restarting ovs agent will eliminate existing port chains' flow rules.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-28 22:16:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-sfc/commit/2f1e25ff568e970dbffc81aace245fe4889047a1', 'message': 'catch up latest ovs agent code

  - current code has bug that when there are some port chain
  - deployed. Then restart the ovs-agent, some flow rules belonging

Change-Id: If83c794230ae1ed34eae2cb1d945a6396e889c8c

commit_message:
Fix bug that restarting ovs agent will eliminate existing port chains' flow rules.

  Neutron ovs agent recently updated its code to eliminate
   all flows rules belonging to each port when the agent restarts.
   For networking-sfc, the flow rules for the port chains need to be
   kept when the ovs agent restarts. This fix modifies the networking-sfc
   ovs agent code to re-setup the port chain related flow rules
   upon OVS agent restart.
  This diff also fixes the errors in tox -epy27.

Change-Id: If83c794230ae1ed34eae2cb1d945a6396e889c8c

commit_message:
Add Senlin plugin for profile and cluster

This patch add Senlin plugin for profile and cluster
resources. It also adds a sample scenario job to test
cluster creating/deleting performance.

commit_message:
Document sorting/pagination extension existance

We now have a way to detect if those features are available to API
users, by checking if 'sorting' and 'pagination' extensions are present
when fetching from /extensions API endpoint.

Change-Id: I2f64a3f1dc34d9ffbc450ef1670ad5d2889cd7c9
Related-Bug: #1566514
Depends-On: I0aaaa037a8ad52060a68dd75c0a1accc6add238e

commit_message:
Modify flatten method to display an empty dict

When a dict is flattened, if a value of an item is empty,
e.g. {"cpu_info": {}}, the item is not displayed.

This patch fixes _flatten method to display such an item including an
empty dict.

Change-Id: I2e4ada0de217c5c4ddea10f3f283c6d8e78083b6
Related-Bug: #1594230

commit_message:
remove start_version arg for keypairs v2.10 shell

start_version is redundant because of decorator
@api_versions.wraps("2.10") on the whole function

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Ib468214490e817a28640a02fb629c762e14828cb

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker refs/changes/67/330667/24 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from tacker.api.v1 import basefrom tacker import managerSUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP = { 'policies': { 'parent': { 'collection_name': 'vnfs', 'member_name': 'vnf' }, 'parameters': { 'name': { 'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None} }, 'type': { 'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None} }, } } } resources = resource_helper.build_resource_info( plugin = manager.TackerManager.get_service_plugins()[ constants.VNFM] for collection_name in SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP: if collection_name.endswith('ies'): resource_name = '%sy' % collection_name[:-3] else: resource_name = collection_name[:-1] parent = SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP[collection_name].get('parent') params = SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP[collection_name].get( 'parameters') controller = base.create_resource(collection_name, resource_name, plugin, params, allow_bulk=True, parent=parent) resource = extensions.ResourceExtension( collection_name, controller, parent, attr_map=params) resources.append(resource) return resources def get_vnf_policies( self, context, vnf_id, filters=None, fields=None): pass @abc.abstractmethod def get_vnf_policy( self, context, vnf_id, policy_id, fields=None): pass @abc.abstractmethod def update_vnf_policy( self, context, vnf_id, policy_id, policy): pass @abc.abstractmethod

subject: Next generation HA architecture work
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-09 16:50:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/b52995437655a32e1e466af4aa338680a2eef52a', 'message': '[WIP - Do not merge] Add a pacemaker light architecture

This is the initial work implementing the lightweight architecture spec
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/299628). Currently it is using a
separate template. The end-goal, once the transition plan has been
agreed upon, is to have a single HA architecture that is lightweight and
to drop the current "full" HA architecture. Ideally, we'd also drop
the non-ha architecture, but for that we best let the light architecture
soak and get tested more.

This will have to be merged once all che composable services
are merged. At that point, once we add all the missing parameters
in puppet modules tracked here:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/puppet-trove/+bug/1579718

we will be able to make the lightweight architecture a
simple environment file (i.e. no special manifest will be needed).
This environment file will do the following:
- Set the needed services to be managed via systemd via the
  OS::TripleO::Services interface
- Set hiera configuration settings needed for the lightweight
  architecture (e.g. -1 for database/max_retries)

Change-Id: I00bccb2563c006f80baed623b64f1e17af20dd4e
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-09 20:06:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/856127ce37cdcc1cf2bcd675f084b199d508c937', 'message': '[WIP - Do not merge] Add a pacemaker light architecture

This is the initial work implementing the lightweight architecture spec
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/299628). Currently it is using a
separate template. The end-goal, once the transition plan has been
agreed upon, is to have a single HA architecture that is lightweight and
to drop the current "full" HA architecture. Ideally, we'd also drop
the non-ha architecture, but for that we best let the light architecture
soak and get tested more.

This will have to be merged once all che composable services
are merged. At that point, once we add all the missing parameters
in puppet modules tracked here:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/puppet-trove/+bug/1579718

we will be able to make the lightweight architecture a
simple environment file (i.e. no special manifest will be needed).
This environment file will do the following:
- Set the needed services to be managed via systemd via the
  OS::TripleO::Services interface
- Set hiera configuration settings needed for the lightweight
  architecture (e.g. -1 for database/max_retries)

Change-Id: I00bccb2563c006f80baed623b64f1e17af20dd4e
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-07-06 16:28:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/c882431a25c6399fc81ab7ed3d3060e43ecb737f', 'message': 'WIP Next generation HA architecture work

commit_message:
Next generation HA architecture work

This is the THT part that brings us the next generation architecture
as described in the following spec:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/299628/

Blueprint:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/ha-lightweight-architecture

So far we tested deployment + tripleo.sh --overcloud-pingtest and
failover + tripleo.sh --overcloud-pingtest

Note that many of the Pacemaker template files become redundant with
this change, but to simplify the process of getting this change landed,
those templates will not be removed until a future commit.

Depends-On: I5e7585c08675d8a4bd071523b94210d325d79b59

Change-Id: I00bccb2563c006f80baed623b64f1e17af20dd4e
Implements: blueprint ha-lightweight-architecture
Co-Author: cmsj@tenshu.net

commit_message:
Improve the help text for vmware datastore driver opts

Change-Id: I6c976612270938da6158488db692f764b7fa4baf
Partial-Bug: #1570946
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance_store refs/changes/86/342286/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: help=_(""" Set verification of the ESX/vCenter server certificate. This configuration option takes in a boolean value to determine whether or not to verify the ESX/vCenter server certificate. If this option is set to true, the ESX/vCenter server certificate is not verified. If this option is set to false, then the default CA truststore is used for verification. This option is ignored if "vmware_ca_file" is set i.e. the ESX/vCenter server certificate will then be verified using the file specified using the "vmware_ca_file" option . Services which consume this: * glance-api * glare-api Possible Values: * True * False Related options: * vmware_ca_file """)), help=_(""" Relative path to the CA bundle file This configuration option enables the operator to use a custom Cerificate Authority File to verify the ESX/vCenter certificate. If this option is set, the "vmware_insecure" option will be ignored and the CA file specified will be used to authenticate the ESX/vCenter server certificate and establish a secure connection to the server. Services which consume this: * glance-api * glare-api Possible Values: * Any string that is a valid relative path to a CA file. Related options: * vmware_insecure """)), help=_(""" A list of datastores where the image can be stored. This configuration option takes in a list of datastores where the image can be stored in the VMWare store backend. This option may be specified multiple times for specifying multiple datastores. The datastore name should be specified after its datacenter path, separated by ":". An optional weight may be given after the datastore name, separated again by ":" to specify the priority. Thus, the required format becomes <datacenter_path>:<datastore_name>:<optional_weight>. When adding an image, the datastore with highest weight will be selected, unless there is not enough free space available in cases where the image size is already known. If no weight is given, it is assumed to be zero and the directory will be considered for selection last. If multiple datastores have the same weight, then the one with the most free space available is selected. Services which consume this: * glance-api * glare-api Possible Values: * Any string of the format <datacenter_path>:<datastore_name>:<optional_weight>. Related options: * None """))]

This option is ignored if ' '"vmware_ca_file" is set.'), help=_('Specify a CA bundle file to use in verifying the ' 'ESX/vCenter server certificate.')), help=_( 'A list of datastores where the image can be stored. This option ' 'may be specified multiple times for specifying multiple ' 'datastores. The datastore name should be specified after its ' 'datacenter path, separated by ":". An optional weight may be ' 'given after the datastore name, separated again by ":". Thus, ' 'the required format becomes ' '<datacenter_path>:<datastore_name>:<optional_weight>. When ' 'adding an image, the datastore with highest weight will be ' 'selected, unless there is not enough free space available in ' 'cases where the image size is already known. If no weight is ' 'given, it is assumed to be zero and the directory will be ' 'considered for selection last. If multiple datastores have the ' 'same weight, then the one with the most free space available is ' 'selected.'))]

commit_message:
Add unit tests for group commands in identity v3

Add unit tests for commands below in identity v3:
group create
group delete
group show
group set
group add user
group remove user
group contains user

Change-Id: I02f3b49e93582245a2749492bba1dfc4c5e0258d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/29/351129/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

columns) self.assertEqual(self.data, data) def test_group_create_or_show(self): self.groups_mock.create.side_effect = ks_exc.Conflict() arglist = [ '--or-show', self.group.name, ] verifylist = [ commit_message:
Remove some properties from overcloud.yaml Controller group

Remove those parameters which simply shadow parameters defined in
puppet/controller.yaml, these can be passed via parameter_defaults,
which is the default.  The remaining properties are more tricky so
will be handled via subsequent patches.

Partially-Implements: blueprint custom-roles
Change-Id: I9bbbd12631de8cb1ad83e265f6ddc9e942dff9ab

The JSON should have the following structure: { "devices": [ { "agent": "AGENT_NAME", "host_mac": "HOST_MAC_ADDRESS", "params": {"PARAM_NAME": "PARAM_VALUE"} } ] } For instance: { "devices": [ { "agent": "fence_xvm", "host_mac": "52:54:00:aa:bb:cc", "params": { "multicast_address": "225.0.0.12", "port": "baremetal_0", "manage_fw": true, "manage_key_file": true, "key_file": "/etc/fence_xvm.key", "key_file_password": "abcdef" } } ] } type: json type: string hidden: true InstanceNameTemplate: default: 'instance-%08x' description: Template string to be used to generate instance names type: string ManageFirewall: default: true description: Whether to manage IPtables rules. type: boolean PurgeFirewallRules: default: false description: Whether IPtables rules should be purged before setting up the ones. type: boolean MysqlInnodbBufferPoolSize: description: > Specifies the size of the buffer pool in megabytes. Setting to zero should be interpreted as "no value" and will defer to the lower level default. type: number default: 0 MysqlMaxConnections: description: Configures MySQL max_connections config setting type: number default: 4096 PublicVirtualInterface: default: 'br-ex' description: > Specifies the interface where the public-facing virtual ip will be assigned. commit_message:
Add overall profiler stats by operation

Change-Id: I07f0dd1bcb15edba4c0184b9c16747fd1bdac840
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/osprofiler refs/changes/51/333951/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: stats = {} op_type = r["info"]["name"] op_started = msec(r["info"]["started"] - self.started_at) op_finished = msec(r["info"]["finished"] - self.started_at) duration = op_finished - op_started r["info"]["started"] = op_started r["info"]["finished"] = op_finished if op_type not in stats: stats[op_type] = { "count": 1, "duration": duration } else: stats[op_type]["count"] += 1 stats[op_type]["duration"] += duration "children": self._build_tree(self.result), "stats": stats
deleted_lines: r["info"]["started"] = msec(r["info"]["started"] - self.started_at) r["info"]["finished"] = msec(r["info"]["finished"] - self.started_at) "children": self._build_tree(self.result)

commit_message:
Update devstack plugin with new auth options

Change-Id: I0a12f010d5b4325ee707bf674adb4813a8721c05
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/12/297312/26 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: configure_auth_token_middleware $IRONIC_CONF_FILE ironic $IRONIC_AUTH_CACHE_DIR/apifunction configure_auth_for { local service_config_section service_config_section=$1 iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE service_config_section auth_type password iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE service_config_section auth_url $KEYSTONE_SERVICE_URI iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE service_config_section username ironic iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE service_config_section password $SERVICE_PASSWORD iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE service_config_section project_name $SERVICE_PROJECT_NAME iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE service_config_section user_domain_id default iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE service_config_section project_domain_id default iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE service_config_section cafile $SSL_BUNDLE_FILE } # set keystone region for all services iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE keystone region_name $REGION_NAME # set keystone auth plugin options for services configure_auth_for neutron configure_auth_for swift configure_auth_for glance configure_auth_for inspector # this one is needed for lookup of Ironic API endpoint via Keystone configure_auth_for conductor
deleted_lines: # TODO(Yuki Nishiwaki): This is a temporary work-around until Ironic is fixed(bug#1422632). # These codes need to be changed to use the function of configure_auth_token_middleware # after Ironic conforms to the new auth plugin. iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE keystone_authtoken identity_uri $KEYSTONE_AUTH_URI iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE keystone_authtoken auth_uri $KEYSTONE_SERVICE_URI/v2.0 iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE keystone_authtoken admin_user ironic iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE keystone_authtoken admin_password $SERVICE_PASSWORD iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE keystone_authtoken admin_tenant_name $SERVICE_PROJECT_NAME iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE keystone_authtoken cafile $SSL_BUNDLE_FILE iniset $IRONIC_CONF_FILE keystone_authtoken signing_dir $IRONIC_AUTH_CACHE_DIR/api

commit_message:
Remove neutron lib warnings from ipv6_utils

Removes:

commit_message:
Depend on the subnet in neutron_basic.yaml

Associating servers or ports with neutron networks actually creates a
dependency with a subnet. Heat can mitigate this in some cases, but we
added subnet properties to our resources so that template authors can
model the actual dependency in the template.

This change specifies that the server refer to the subnet as well as
the network to avoid the race where the subnet has not been created
yet.

The subnet property has been available since Liberty for
OS::Nova::Server, so I think its time we considered deprecating the
network property.

Change-Id: If7cd27ab4628fd1c1d0401d0a5c411ee5053361d
Closes-Bug: #1546201
Closes-Bug: #1547261

commit_message:
Quote user_id that is consist of numbers only

Though the user_id that contains only numbers, for example 1234,
is valid Zanata ID, it raises an exception:

  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "./zanata_stats.py", line 271, in <module>
      main()
    File "./zanata_stats.py", line 261, in main
      language_teams, options.project)
    File "./zanata_stats.py", line 166, in get_zanata_stats
      user_contributes = statisticdata[user_id]
  KeyError: 1234

Change-Id: Id1325204d6979190d3c4c6ae5410960fe221b57e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/i18n refs/changes/54/350954/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

VNFD legacy template deprecation warning

TOSCA templates. This is client-side patch.

This consists of the removal of the openstack-core resource

architecture, effectively become dead code and there is no point is

commit_message:
Next generation HA architecture work

This change moves the cinder-volume/cinder-scheduler constraints in the
cinder-scheduler profile as these can't be applied by the cinder-volume
service when cinder-scheduler isn't managed by Pacemaker.

Blueprint:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/ha-lightweight-architecture

Change-Id: I5e7585c08675d8a4bd071523b94210d325d79b59
Implements: blueprint ha-lightweight-architecture
Co-Author: cmsj@tenshu.net

commit_message:
Corrected execution step for devstack

Execution of devstack script may not start on some
machines because some of the machine may not have
current directory in PATH variables. Correction
has been made to start the script independent of
the environment.

Change-Id: Ib7f9b691a9567f22f7d81bf725cc89d69cdd229b
Closes-Bug: #1598694

commit_message:
Add proxy config option to google backup driver

Enable users to specify a proxy URL for connecting the cinder
backup service to GCS.

URIOpt was changed to StrOpt during the backport because
URIOpt is a feature added in version 3.12.0 of oslo_config
which is not supported in mitaka.

DocImpact: New config option for google backup driver.
Change-Id: I46d2b5d202644269ed44abded3fab8dcc230e3da
Closes-Bug: #1592730
(cherry picked from commit 4080179c8b9a60ee7215c7daaf05a2fc40140cfc)
Co-Authored-By: Ollie Leahy <oliver.leahy@hp.com>
