commit_message:
network: Fix nova boot with multiple security-groups

Booting an instance with 'default' + other security-groups doesn't
apply the 'default' security-group on the instance.
Nova is required to remove the 'default' security-group from the request
to Neutron when it's the only security-group that should be applied on
the instance.
This bug is a result of change
I630008a9733624a9d9b59b7aa3b8b2a3f8985d61.

Conflicts:
        nova/tests/unit/network/test_neutronv2.py

Closes-Bug: #1572171
Change-Id: I3eb685f4d82615d3ebd25e7471de47129c78c86a
(cherry picked from commit 93fde493aceb47d74b84c7c8665bba5bd8ea1797)

This is currently *only* used for bigswitch integration, which doesn't
do any upgrade testing. The strategic direction is to use plugins
instead.

subject: Use more specific asserts in tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-04 10:48:10.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/tests/unit/identity/test_backends.py', 'keystone/tests/unit/test_v3.py', 'keystone/tests/unit/trust/test_backends.py', 'keystone/tests/unit/common/test_notifications.py', 'keystone/tests/unit/core.py', 'keystone/tests/unit/test_backend_sql.py', 'keystone/tests/unit/test_v3_os_revoke.py', 'keystone/tests/unit/test_v3_filters.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/ffd2fea754d609d1e3ddc284b1dd60b81b49f083', 'message': 'Use more specific asserts in tests

Instead of assertTrue and assertFalse use more specific asserts.
They are compatible with Python 2.7[1] and 3.4[2]

[1]: https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/unittest.html
[2]: https://docs.python.org/3.4/library/unittest.html

Change-Id: Id9f73e90f0786ef7576edd2f97aa31b1503c14dd
'}]
commit_message:
Use more specific asserts in tests

Instead of assertTrue and assertFalse use more specific asserts.
They are compatible with Python 2.7[1] and 3.4[2]

[1]: https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/unittest.html
[2]: https://docs.python.org/3.4/library/unittest.html

Change-Id: Id9f73e90f0786ef7576edd2f97aa31b1503c14dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/18/351118/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertLessEqual( before_time, event_issued_before, self.assertLessEqual( event_issued_before, after_time,
deleted_lines: self.assertTrue( before_time <= event_issued_before, self.assertTrue( event_issued_before <= after_time,

commit_message:
Remove discover from test-requirements

It's only needed for python < 2.7 which is not supported

commit_message:
Add goal_id, strategy_id and host_aggregate CLI options to audit

Add goal_id, strategy_id and host_aggregate CLI options to audit
so that an audit doesn't lose important information when an audit
template is deleted. Also, user can input a specific strategy to
accomplish a goal for an audit.

Partially-Implements: blueprint persistent-audit-parameters
Depends-On: I7b3eae4d0752a11208f5f92ee13ab1018d8521ad

checks and signals used by a test to the debug log.

commit_message:
Fix Django 1.9 unit tests

The last horizon change [1] has fixed the form_invalid call.
Now all form data are obtained properly and there is no need
in a custom form_invalid method. UT are changed accordingly.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/337703/

Change-Id: I18c0ed61fdd86421333527832381f88e9e3cb5e9
Closes-Bug: #1609806

commit_message:
Group advanced topics by type

We're getting to have a lot of "advanced" docs, and most of those
fit into one of a few categories.  This change separates the
advanced topics into one of the following categories:

-Feature Config
-Baremetal Node Config
-Backend Config
-Custom Config
-Developer Docs

Single image building is moved to post deployment since it's not
a normal part of the initial deployment.

Change-Id: I14e31469a533efbfe3c18c4bd11da8b3f8f455e6

commit_message:
Update the home-page info with the developer documentation

Since there are so many components in openstack,
by describing the URL info in the configuration file,
it is more convenient to find the developer documentation
than from the unified portal

pypowervm/tasks/hdisk/__init__.py, and the method contents into private
modules within that package.  The change is transparent to consuming
code - except in unit tests which mock.patch symbols that are invoked
from *within* methods invoked by the consuming code (which we shouldn't
be patching anyway).

commit_message:
Rebase on pypowervm.tasks.hdisk refactor

pypowervm recently moved the symbols from pypowervm/tasks/hdisk.py to
pypowervm/tasks/hdisk/__init__.py, and the method contents into private
modules within that package.  The change is transparent to consuming
code - except in unit tests which mock.patch symbols that are invoked
from *within* methods invoked by the consuming code (which we shouldn't
be patching anyway).

For example, pypowervm.tasks.hdisk contains discover_hdisk and
lua_recovery, where the former invokes the latter.  If consuming unit
tests patch pypowervm.tasks.hdisk.lua_recovery, the patch will be
missed, since it is actually looked up by pypowervm itself as
pypowervm.tasks.hdisk.{private_module}.lua_recovery.

This change set refactors unit tests such that we're always patching the
first-level methods from pypowervm.tasks.hdisk.

Change-Id: I8415c86d97187dd98eb1e67164b93e59ec61c599
Closes-Bug: 1607467

commit_message:
Add spec for AMQP 1.0 Dispatch Router

This specification describes a new messaging backend service for
Oslo.Messaging. This new backend is a brokerless, message-routed mesh.
This backend will be supported by the existing AMQP 1.0 driver. This
specification introduces the concept of a message-routed mesh and
describes how the existing AMQP 1.0 driver will be re-factored to
support it.

Change-Id: I84698db18cc76bc28b9d476771b591f4d738c03d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/03/314603/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================ Add Support for a Router-based Message Bus ============================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo?searchtext=amqp-dispatch-router This specification proposes changes to the existing AMQP 1.0 driver that will provide support for the Qpid Dispatch Router message bus as an RPC transport. The Notification pattern will not be supported in the Newton timeframe and will be introduced in a later release. The blueprint for the original driver can be found here [1]_ and the original architecture is described in [2]_. The changes described by this specification are a refactoring of the original design. Support for the Qpid C++ Router (qpidd) will be preserved. Problem description =================== The Qpid C++ Broker was the only messaging service that supported the AMQP 1.0 protocol when the original driver was developed. As such, the original driver was designed and tested against a broker intermediary. An alternative to the traditional broker-centric messaging architecture has become available since the driver was originally developed. The Qpid Dispatch Router provides a decentralized, highly redundant, scalable messaging network that is quite different from the traditional centralized single-broker model. This specification will describe the changes to the existing AMQP 1.0 driver necessary for using Oslo Messaging services across a dispatch router network. The Qpid Dispatch Router is a stateless *message switch* that routes messages to their destination using a shortest path algorithm. Think of it as an internet router, but at the message address level instead of IP address. The router is **not a broker**. It differs from broker in the following significant ways: * it is deployed with other routers as a network * the router is queue-less * it never accepts ownership of a message * any acknowledgement is end-to-end * availability is provided by redundancy, not clustering * it aims for availability of the communication pathways rather than of individual messages * it allows other message services to plug into the network Unlike a broker a messaging bus composed of a single router is sub-optimal. The router is designed to be deployed in a network of inter-connected router nodes. Each router has dedicated TCP connections to one or more of its peers. Clients connect to the network by connecting to one of the routers using a single TCP connection. When a client creates a subscription the address used for the subscription is propagated beyond the locally-connected router. All routers in the network become aware of the subscription and compute an optimal path from each router back to the consuming client. When another client publishes to that subscription the routers forward the message along the appropriate path to the subscriber which consumes the message. Note well that when a message transits a router on its way to its final destination no queueing is done. To be specific, none of the routers along the path claim ownership of the message - i.e. the routers do not acknowledge the message. Instead the ack from the consuming client is propagated back through the network to the origin sender. In other words, the router network does *end-to-end acknowledgement*. In contrast a broker *does* claim ownership of the message. However, an ack coming from the broker does not guarantee that the message will be consumed. It merely indicates that the message has been queued. Since routers compute the optimal path for a message it is possible to configure redundant paths across the messaging network. By deploying the routers over a redundant physical network it becomes possible to suffer a degree of infrastructure loss without affecting the messaging service. Given that the routers themselves are stateless there is no need for a clustering capability as there is in broker deployments. While the network may be partitioned due to infrastructure failure, there is no possibility of 'split-brain' occurring as there is no master/slave relationship among connected routers. All routers are equal peers. The router network itself cannot provide a message store-and-forward service since the routers are queue-less. However brokers provide excellent store-and-forward capabilities and can be integrated into the router network for exactly that purpose. The Qpid Dispatch Router supports the notion of a *waypoint*. A waypoint is a special class of clients that act as a central authority for a defined message address space. Messages that are published under the waypoint address space are delivered to the waypoint instead of being sent to the consuming endpoint. Likewise all subscribers to that address space consume from the waypoint rather than the publishers. By configuring a broker waypoint it becomes possible to queue messages of a pre-defined address prefix. The broker may be clustered or use durable backing store - none of which is the concern of the router network. This feature makes it possible to support notification messages, which usually require store-and-forward semantics. Support for broker waypoints and notification traffic are not a target of the Newton release but will be provided at a later release. The Qpid C++ Broker currently supports the waypoint function. In the future the ActiveMQ broker will be able to act as a waypoint too. The following is a depiction of a four routers interconnected in a mesh topology:: +-----------+ +-----------+ |RPC Server1| |RPC Caller1| +-----+-----+ +----+------+ | | | | +---v----+ +---v----+ |Router A+#########+Router B| +---+----+ +----+---+ <------+ # ## ## # | # ## ## # +---+--+ # ## # |Broker| # ## ## # +------+ # ## ## # +---+----+ +-----+--+ <------+ |Router C+#########+Router D| +-----+-----+ +---+----+ +-----+--+ |RPC Caller2| ^ ^ +-----------+ | | | | +------+----+ ++----------+ |RPC Caller3| |RPC Server2| +-----------+ +-----------+ The '#' denote the inter-router connections among Router A, B, C, and D. Router A has a single RPC server client attached. Router B has both an RPC caller and a broker attached. Another RPC caller is attached to Router C. An RPC server and an RPC caller are attached to Router D. Since shortest path routing is used RPC call/cast messages from RPC Caller3 to RPC Server1 would only transit Router A and Router C. Likewise RPC calls from Caller1 to Server2 would transit Router B and Router D. RPC Caller2 invoking a method on Server2 would only transit Router D. In this example notice that only those routers along the shortest path between two communicating endpoints are involved in the message transfer. This provides for a degree of parallelism not possible when using a single broker backend. More information about the router can be found here [3]_. Proposed change =============== Three issues need to be resolved in the driver in order to support RPC over a routed messaging network: * optimal message addressing * credit management * undeliverable messages Addressing ---------- The current addressing scheme embeds the message delivery semantics into the prefix of the address. This prefix is used by the Qpid C++ Broker to automatically provision the proper node - either queue or topic - for a given publish/subscribe request. For more detail refer to [2]_. Since both the router and the broker identify themselves during connection set up it will be possible to introduce a new addressing syntax while preserving the existing syntax for backward compatibility. The original address syntax used when connected to a broker will remain unchanged. The new address syntax will only be used when the driver connects to a router network. When comparing addresses the router employs a *longest prefix match* algorithm. In contrast traditional brokers tend to use either a pattern match or a simple exact match. The router address syntax will use the prefix of the address as an address space classification. There are a few additional points to consider for routable addressing that do not apply for broker addressing: * Other applications may reside on the same network. The addressing scheme should be designed to avoid collisions with an address space in use by a completely separate set of applications. * Application aware routing. It should be possible to distinguish RPC-related traffic from Notification traffic at the address level. This will allow the routers to route notification traffic to a broker(s) while RPC messages can travel point to point. * Configurable routing subdomains. It should be possible to further partition traffic on a per-project basis. This could provide some traffic isolation between projects as well as allow for parallel oslo.messaging buses on the same network. And like the existing address structure the delivery semantics (e.g. fanout, direct, shared, etc.) must be provided to the network in order to ensure the desired delivery pattern is used. For RPC services there are four patterns that addressing must allow: * direct to a given server * shared queue (competing consumers) * fanout * direct reply The following address syntax is proposed for the first three of the above patterns respectively:: openstack.org/om/rpc/unicast/$EXCHANGE/$TOPIC/$SERVER openstack.org/om/rpc/anycast/$EXCHANGE/$TOPIC openstack.org/om/rpc/multicast/$EXCHANGE/$TOPIC The prefix 'openstack.org' establishes the root domain of the address space and is reserved for use only by OpenStack applications. The 'om' tag further classifies this address as belonging to the oslo.messaging service. Reserving the address space prefixed by the string 'openstack.org/om' for oslo.messaging's use will avoid collisions should other applications also use the routing network. The 'rpc' segment classifies the RPC service address space. 'notify' may appear instead of 'rpc' in this address segment; is reserved for the future support of notification traffic. The 'rpc' and 'notify' tags will be used to identify the service. This allows notification traffic to be sent to a broker while RPC traffic can be sent point to point. The 'unicast', 'multicast', and 'anycast' keywords determine the messaging semantics that need to be applied when delivering a message. 'unicast' causes the message is to be delivered to one subscriber. 'anycast' causes the message to be delivered to one subscriber among many [TBD]_. For 'multicast' the router(s) will deliver a copy of the message to all subscribers. .. [TBD] I seem to recall that the oslo.messaging API guaranteed *strict* round-robin delivery of RPC Requests and Notifications across subscribers in the case where multiple servers/listeners are subscribed to the same target. Is this still the case? There are cases where strict round-robin delivery is actually sub-optimal and a more relaxed distribution pattern would be more appropriate. For example, a routed network can monitor credit levels across all consumers and can detect when individual consumers are not keeping up with the message arrival rate (due to message processing delays). This allows the router to deliver the message to a different client - one that is not exhibiting such a high backlog. Doing so would be optimal, but would most likely violate a strict round-robin guarantee. Additionally, when not under load it would be optimal to deliver the message to the consumer on the least cost path (e.g. lower link cost and/or fewer inter-router hops), which could also violate strict round-robin guarantees. If at all possible I would like to avoid enforcing strict round robin delivery in this driver. The values for $EXCHANGE, $TOPIC, and $SERVER are all taken from the Target used for the subscription (or the destination when call/casting). It is possible to use the $EXCHANGE value to provide further isolation of traffic based on the application's configuration. An RPC Server for a given Target will subscribe to all three of the above addresses. The RPC Client will address its message to one of the three variants depending on whether the destination is a specific server, fanout, or just the topic. RPC Reply addressing will work as it does today. The RPC Reply address is dynamically assigned to the driver by the message bus (broker or router) and is considered an opaque value. The driver will simply set the RPC Call message's reply-to field to this value before sending the message. The IncomingMessage will use this reply-to value as the reply message's address. A single reply address will be used per TCP connection to the bus as is done today. RPC Call messages will be assigned a unique message identifier that will be written to the 'id' field of the message header. The RPC Server will place this identifier in the reply message's 'content-id' field before sending it. Received reply messages will be de-muxed using the message's 'content-id' value and sent to the proper waiter. Credit Management ----------------- Since the router network is unable to queue messages it must not accept messages from publishers if there is not a consumer ready to consume the message. This requirement is enforced by the use of message credit as defined by the AMQP 1.0 protocol. The router will not grant credit to a message publisher unless there is at least one consumer subscribed to the message's address that has granted credit to the network. This differs considerably from the current broker-based solutions. In the case of a broker if a publisher attempts to send a message for which there is no consumer the broker will automatically create a queue or topic in anticipation that a consumer for the message will appear at a later time. The broker then queues the message and an acknowledgement is sent to the publisher. At this point the publisher considers the message delivered and can proceed to other tasks. In the case of a routed network this approach is impossible as queues cannot be created by the network itself. Note that there is an exception to this in the case of a broker waypoint which can create a queue for arriving messages. But in the non-brokered RPC case a good credit management strategy must be implemented. The driver will distribute credit on a per subscription basis. Each RPC server subscribes to three separate addresses as per the description above. There is also the per-transport shared reply address subscription. Each subscription will make this credit available to the router network which will in turn distribute it among clients publishing to those addresses. It is critical that the shared reply subscription always has credit available for replies coming from the RPC Servers. Otherwise an RPC Server can block attempting to send a reply to one particular client. This would result in all RPC calls to that server also blocking (i.e. head-of-line blocking). Fortunately the RPC call pattern is self-limiting: a caller is blocked from sending any further requests until a reply is received (or the call times out). This means that back pressuring the RPC callers is probably unnecessary. Therefore the driver will grant a large batch of credit to the reply subscription. The driver will monitor the credit level as messages arrive and are passed up to the client, replenishing credit as needed. The batch size will be configurable with a default of 500 credits. This default may be altered in the course of tuning the driver's performance. The RPC Server subscriptions cannot be as generous with credit as the reply subscription. The server needs to apply some backpressure in the event that it fails to keep up with the incoming RPC calls and casts. Otherwise too many incoming messages will be buffered in the driver. The goal will be to limit the amount of internal message buffering per server while minimizing the performance impact. Each subscription will be granted a batch of 50 credits by default. This default is configurable on a per subscription basis and may be adjusted in the course of tuning. The driver will replenish credit back to the default level once credit drops below one half of the default level. The credit level check will be performed at the point where the client acknowledges the message. This will limit the worst case buffering to about 150 messages per server. For tuning purposes the driver will maintain a count of detected credit stalls - when the amount of outstanding credit hits zero before the driver can replenish it. The driver will issue a debug log message when this event is detected. Credit must also be accounted for at the publisher's side. The driver must deal intelligently with the lack of available credit. If the driver were to ignore credit when publishing the messages may never be written to the network. There would be no way to prevent an unlimited number of messages being buffered in the driver waiting to be sent. There is not much to be worried about for the case of an RPC caller. An RPC caller must block until the reply is received or the call times out. If no credit is made available during the timeout period the call will simply fail as it would if no reply were received in time. An RPC cast is not much different - it will block until the message is acknowledged. However in the case of this driver that acknowledge will be coming from the endpoint rather than an intermediate broker. In any case should no credit become available before the timeout occurs the cast will simply fail. An RPC fanout cast is similar to the unicast cast case but even simpler yet as fanout messages are sent 'pre-acked'. The client will only block for credit in the fanout case. The only caveat is that the oslo.messaging API does not *enforce* use of a timeout in any of the above cases. It is quite legal to 'block forever' waiting for a reply or acknowledgement. This is an obvious a bug in the case of an RPC call, but it is likely this is being done in the case of cast and fanout. Remember that a broker will create a queue on demand if a consumer is not present. This means that casts and fanouts will always be acked as long as there is a broker present. In general by auto-creating a queue the broker allows the application to 'ride out' any delay or absence of a legitimate consumer. There is no telling how many applications have come to rely on this behavior. Unless the driver compensates for this in some way it is likely that things will break badly. The driver will account for this by mandating a timeout for every message that is sent to the router network. In the case where the RPCClient has a timeout configured that timeout will apply to all messages sent from that client. When no timeout is provided by the application a default timeout will be used. The value of the default timeout can be configured. This default timeout will never be used to set the message's TTL, unlike a timeout explicitly set by the application. The proposed default timeout for RPC calls will be 30 seconds. Since cast blocks for an acknowledgement from the destination it too will use a 30 second default timeout. Fanout does not wait for acknowledgement and will use a 10 second timeout when waiting for credit. Credit must also be considered when sending RPC replies. However, RPC replies are a bit different. First, the maximum number of pending replies will be limited to the number of RPC calls currently being processed. These incoming call messages are already bound by the amount of credit granted by the RPC Server. This indirectly bounds the rate of outgoing RPC replies. Second, when replying it is critical that the RPC Server never block indefinitely waiting for credit from the RPC client. This will cause the entire server to hang, affecting other clients with pending requests. Although the client's driver will grant a large amount of credit to the reply subscription there still exists the possibility that the client has become unreachable since the RPC call was processed. The client may have crashed or the network may have lost connectivity. To prevent this a default timeout will be applied to the RPC reply call. The driver will also send RPC replies pre-acknowledged since there is very little the RPC Server can do to recover in the case of a dropped reply message. Therefore the RPC Server only has to wait for credit to become available and can use a relatively short timeout. The default timeout for RPC replies will be 10 seconds. Undeliverable Messages ---------------------- It is possible that the destination of a message may become unreachable while the message transits the router network. The consumer may have crashed or a network failure may occur leaving the message with nowhere to go. In this case the router network will send a negative acknowledgement back to the original sender. This takes the form of an AMQP 1.0 disposition performative with a terminal delivery state of either MODIFIED or RELEASED. These states notify the original sender that the message was never delivered. The client may retransmit the message at a later time and be confident there is no risk of duplication. However there is no guarantee that message order will be preserved should the client retransmit the message. Therefore retransmission should only occur when the client is confident that the operation represented by the message is idempotent within the message stream. This pattern can be used by the driver to implement the optional 'requeue' feature defined by oslo.messaging. When a consumer invokes the requeue method on an incoming message the driver can send a disposition with terminal state RELEASED back to the publisher. That's the easy part. The hard part is deciding what the publisher should do when it receives the RELEASED disposition. In the brokered case the message is simply made available for re-consumption. This is not possible in a routed network - it is up to the original publisher to determine what to do with the message. The publisher may elect to re-transmit the message, possibly after a short delay, but there is no guarantee the router network will re-deliver the message to a different consumer. This is one case where strict round robin delivery would work to our advantage. Re-delivery will not be a goal of the Newton release. The driver will simply treat the reception of a RELEASED or MODIFIED disposition as a message delivery failure. This may be addressed in a different fashion in a future release. Alternatives ------------ There are other alternative messaging backends that at first glance appear to offer similar capabilities as a dispatch router network. ZeroMQ, for example, is also a non-brokered solution. ZeroMQ also provides a point to point messaging pattern that can be used for RPC services. However, there are some significant differences between ZeroMQ and a routed network. First, clients of a routed network only require a single TCP connection to the router network, whereas the ZeroMQ implementation uses a TCP connection per destination. In other words a ZeroMQ RPC Server will require a TCP connection to every RPC client it communicates with. Therefore ZeroMQ will require more TCP-related resources as the number of RPC Servers and clients scale up. Second, in a router network there is no need to have all clients reachable via TCP as is required by ZeroMQ. The router network does message-layer routing, not IP address routing. This allows clients and servers on separate private IP subnets to interoperate using the router network as a bridge. These subnets do not need to be visible to each other over an IP network. For example, RPC Servers may reside on a private subnet in Company A, while the RPC Clients reside on a different private subnet in Company B. This can be accomplished by ZeroMQ but would require proper configuration of firewalls and NAT'ing. It also provides for better load-balancing where a call is made on a service group. The client is not responsible for determining which service instance in the group should get the message. Lastly, the router network inherently provides service discovery. A dedicated service discovery component is not needed. A federated broker network is another messaging bus that is somewhat like the router network. However a routed network is a much better solution for distributed messaging. In fact the Qpid Dispatch Router project was started explicitly to provide a better solution than broker federation for distributed messaging. Versions of AMQP previous to 1.0 *required* a broker intermediary. Therefore the only way to distribute messages prior to 1.0 was to develop a broker-based routing solution. The 1.0 version of the protocol drops this broker intermediary requirement. This makes a routed messaging network possible. A network of lightweight, stateless message switches augmented by brokers only where store and forward is needed can completely supplant a federated broker deployment in terms of functionality. Messages travelling through a broker federation are queued at each node, unlike a routed network. This increases latency, hurts throughput, and removes the possibility of end-to-end acknowledgement. This makes it harder for the ‘client’ to know when to resend the request and for the ‘service’ to know when to resend a response. It can lead to trying to make the broker replicate all messages which makes scaling harder. The router network is not the right solution for all deployments. A single broker is a much simpler solution if it can meet a deployment's messaging requirements. ZeroMQ will be a good choice for those distributed deployments not bound by routing or TCP resource constraints. Likewise there will be deployments where a router network will be the optimal messaging backend. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- The existing API should not require any changes. These changes will preserve compatibility with existing qpidd-based deployments. Security impact --------------- Locking down a distributed message bus will by definition be more involved than securing a single broker instance. However, the Qpid Dispatch Router supports the same security framework as the Qpid C++ broker. Specifically: * TLS support, including client authentication via certificates * SASL authentication, including Kerberos support * Policy via ACLs To be explicit TLS and/or SASL may be used on the router-client connections as well as the inter-router connections. The driver already supports TLS and SASL configuration for the Qpid broker. The same configuration options will apply for the router network. Performance Impact ------------------ Any performance impact should be limited to the users of the AMQP 1.0 driver. Users of other drivers such as RabbitMQ will not be affected. There may be an effect on the performance as it now stands with the Qpid broker, however every effort will be made to minimize this. Configuration Impact -------------------- New configuration items for credit and timeout duration will be added. The default values for these options will be determined as the driver is tuned for performance. These items include: * Credit limit for Reply subscription * Credit limit for Server subscription * Credit limit for Topic subscription * Credit limit for Fanout subscription * default RPC call timeout (TBD: may already exist?) * default cast timeout * default fanout timeout * default reply timeout Developer Impact ---------------- Any new features added to oslo.messaging that must be implemented via driver modification would need to be implemented in this driver as well. Testing Impact -------------- The Qpid Dispatch Router will need to be available in the CI environment in order to fully test this driver. This is gated by inclusion of the router packages and its dependencies into Debian testing. The Apache Qpid community is in the process of submitting the following packages for inclusion in Debian: * qpid-dispatch-router * qpid-dispatch-router-tools * python-qpid-proton * qpid-proton-c * pyngus These packages are already available in the EPEL repositories. The driver must pass the existing amqp1 driver tests. The driver must pass the gate-oslo.messaging-src-dsvm-full and gate-oslo.messaging-dsvm-functional tests. Devstack already supports using a standalone router [4]_. It may be necessary to add the qpidd broker as the notification transport in order to pass the above gate tests. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: kgiusti@gmail.com (kgiusti on IRC) Other contributors: ansmith@redhat.com Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: newton Work Items ---------- * Implement new addressing syntax * Implement credit handling * Implement new configuration items * Update documentation * Functional test integration * Upstream CI integration Incubation ========== None. Adoption -------- It is unlikely that this driver will be adopted in the majority of use cases as a single broker is usually sufficient. Adoption is more likely among those deployments that have medium to large clouds deployed across a distributed network topology. Library ------- oslo.messaging Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- None Documentation Impact ==================== The library's AMQP 1.0 documentation will need to be updated for the new backend [5]_. Dependencies ============ The driver will require no additional dependencies. References ========== .. [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+spec/amqp10-driver-implementation .. [2] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/oslo-specs/tree/specs/juno/amqp10-driver-implementation.rst .. [3] http://qpid.apache.org/components/dispatch-router/index.html .. [4] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/devstack-plugin-amqp1/commit/?id=142d975ac38a6a22c3a1eee6f43009d2098b270d .. [5] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.messaging/AMQP1.0.html .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Optimiz the help information for audit type parameter.

I want to create a audit from audit template, I don't know correct
audit type value I can use. So I optimize the help information for
audit create shell command.

Change-Id: Idee3bb2e62c9cdb9bf70cced4acbc4df4f8a968c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-watcherclient refs/changes/26/351026/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: help=_("Audit type. It must be ONESHOT or CONTINUOUS. " "Default is ONESHOT."))

subject: Prevent syslog leakage
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-04 13:22:02.000000000', 'files': ['files/50-default.conf'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-rsyslog_client/commit/3bcfed8a37a6f09b0ca2b106fb7adfcd72b1e371', 'message': 'Prevent syslog leakage

To prevent leakage to syslog this commit adds local7 to the list
of excluded facilities in the rsyslog client default configuration
file. This was done because local7 is used as a facility for
openstack services to send log messages and by not excluding it
in the default config file it was sending the log messages to
syslog and the correct log file for the services.

Change-Id: Ia938c1266dac51e6f278cadc8272ac98bb270044
Partial-Bug: 1588051
(cherry picked from commit eea5c79e96a222abf161d0cfa70b19589495e241)
'}]
commit_message:
Prevent syslog leakage

To prevent leakage to syslog this commit adds local7 to the list
of excluded facilities in the rsyslog client default configuration
file. This was done because local7 is used as a facility for
openstack services to send log messages and by not excluding it
in the default config file it was sending the log messages to
syslog and the correct log file for the services.

Change-Id: Ia938c1266dac51e6f278cadc8272ac98bb270044
Partial-Bug: 1588051
(cherry picked from commit eea5c79e96a222abf161d0cfa70b19589495e241)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-rsyslog_client refs/changes/82/351182/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: *.*;local7,auth,authpriv.none -/var/log/syslog

called without specified property to unset.

commit_message:
Add cinder volumes attachment tests

This commit adds cinder volumes support tests for app deployment:
 - with existing volume
 - with volume creation
 - with volume from image creation
 - with volume from volume creation
 - with volume from snapshot creation
 - with volume from backup creation
 - with volume creation, multiattach and readonly on
 - which using boot volume as image

Change-Id: Ie1e0f050faf3bdc0b32f7bda15d78995434ee812
targets: bp normalize-murano-tests
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/46/339446/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2016 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from murano_tempest_tests import utils from murano_tempest_tests.tests.scenario import base class TestCinderVolumes(base.BaseScenarioTest): @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): super(TestCinderVolumes, cls).resource_setup() @classmethod def resource_cleanup(cls): super(TestCinderVolumes, cls).resource_cleanup() def test_deploy_app_with_existing_volume(self): volume = self.create_volume() #TODO: Add volume cleanup name = utils.generate_name('testMurano') environment = self.application_catalog_client.create_environment(name) session = self.application_catalog_client.\ create_session(environment['id']) self.assertEqual(environment['id'], session['environment_id']) volume_attributes = { "/dev/vdb": { "?": { "type": "io.murano.resources.ExistingCinderVolume" }, "openstackId": volume } } post_body = self.apache_cinder(attributes=volume_attributes) self.application_catalog_client.\ create_service(environment['id'], session['id'], post_body) self.deploy_environment(environment, session) self.check_volume_attached('testMurano', volume) def test_deploy_app_with_volume_creation_from_snapshot(self): volume = self.create_volume() snapshot = self.create_snapshot(volume) self.addCleanup(self.snapshot_client.delete_snapshot, snapshot) #TODO: Add volume cleanup name = utils.generate_name('Test_Murano') environment = self.application_catalog_client.create_environment(name) session = self.application_catalog_client.\ create_session(environment['id']) self.assertEqual(environment['id'], session['environment_id']) volume_attributes = { "/dev/vdb": { "?": { "type": "io.murano.resources.CinderVolume" }, "size": 1, "sourceSnapshot": { "?": { "type": "io.murano.resources.CinderVolumeSnapshot" }, "openstackId": snapshot } } } post_body = self.apache_cinder(volume_attributes) self.application_catalog_client.\ create_service(environment['id'], session['id'], post_body) self.deploy_environment(environment, session)

commit_message:
Add authtoken class

Add authtoken class like we do in all other modules, to configure
[authtoken] section.

Change-Id: I5bc4df614ae78d665156c7afeb443169c24be533
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-cookiecutter refs/changes/97/350797/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # class: {{cookiecutter.project_name}}::keystone::auth # # Configure the keystone_authtoken section in the configuration file # # === Parameters # # [*username*] # (Optional) The name of the service user # Defaults to '{{cookiecutter.project_name}}' # # [*password*] # (Required) Password to create for the service user # # [*auth_url*] # (Optional) The URL to use for authentication. # Defaults to 'http://localhost:35357'. # # [*project_name*] # (Optional) Service project name # Defaults to 'services' # # [*user_domain_name*] # (Optional) Name of domain for $username # Defaults to $::os_service_default # # [*project_domain_name*] # (Optional) Name of domain for $project_name # Defaults to $::os_service_default # # [*insecure*] # (Optional) If true, explicitly allow TLS without checking server cert # against any certificate authorities. WARNING: not recommended. Use with # caution. # Defaults to $:os_service_default # # [*auth_section*] # (Optional) Config Section from which to load plugin specific options # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*auth_type*] # (Optional) Authentication type to load # Defaults to $::os_service_default # # [*auth_uri*] # (Optional) Complete public Identity API endpoint. # Defaults to 'http://localhost:5000'. # # [*auth_version*] # (Optional) API version of the admin Identity API endpoint. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*cache*] # (Optional) Env key for the swift cache. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*cafile*] # (Optional) A PEM encoded Certificate Authority to use when verifying HTTPs # connections. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*certfile*] # (Optional) Required if identity server requires client certificate # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*check_revocations_for_cached*] # (Optional) If true, the revocation list will be checked for cached tokens. # This requires that PKI tokens are configured on the identity server. # boolean value. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*delay_auth_decision*] # (Optional) Do not handle authorization requests within the middleware, but # delegate the authorization decision to downstream WSGI components. Boolean # value # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*enforce_token_bind*] # (Optional) Used to control the use and type of token binding. Can be set # to: "disabled" to not check token binding. "permissive" (default) to # validate binding information if the bind type is of a form known to the # server and ignore it if not. "strict" like "permissive" but if the bind # type is unknown the token will be rejected. "required" any form of token # binding is needed to be allowed. Finally the name of a binding method that # must be present in tokens. String value. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*hash_algorithms*] # (Optional) Hash algorithms to use for hashing PKI tokens. This may be a # single algorithm or multiple. The algorithms are those supported by Python # standard hashlib.new(). The hashes will be tried in the order given, so put # the preferred one first for performance. The result of the first hash will # be stored in the cache. This will typically be set to multiple values only # while migrating from a less secure algorithm to a more secure one. Once all # the old tokens are expired this option should be set to a single value for # better performance. List value. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*http_connect_timeout*] # (Optional) Request timeout value for communicating with Identity API # server. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*http_request_max_retries*] # (Optional) How many times are we trying to reconnect when communicating # with Identity API Server. Integer value # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*include_service_catalog*] # (Optional) Indicate whether to set the X-Service-Catalog header. If False, # middleware will not ask for service catalog on token validation and will # not # set the X-Service-Catalog header. Boolean value. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*keyfile*] # (Optional) Required if identity server requires client certificate # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*memcache_pool_conn_get_timeout*] # (Optional) Number of seconds that an operation will wait to get a memcached # client connection from the pool. Integer value # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*memcache_pool_dead_retry*] # (Optional) Number of seconds memcached server is considered dead before it # is tried again. Integer value # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*memcache_pool_maxsize*] # (Optional) Maximum total number of open connections to every memcached # server. Integer value # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*memcache_pool_socket_timeout*] # (Optional) Number of seconds a connection to memcached is held unused in # the # pool before it is closed. Integer value # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*memcache_pool_unused_timeout*] # (Optional) Number of seconds a connection to memcached is held unused in # the # pool before it is closed. Integer value # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*memcache_secret_key*] # (Optional, mandatory if memcache_security_strategy is defined) This string # is used for key derivation. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*memcache_security_strategy*] # (Optional) If defined, indicate whether token data should be authenticated # or # authenticated and encrypted. If MAC, token data is authenticated (with # HMAC) # in the cache. If ENCRYPT, token data is encrypted and authenticated in the # cache. If the value is not one of these options or empty, auth_token will # raise an exception on initialization. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*memcache_use_advanced_pool*] # (Optional) Use the advanced (eventlet safe) memcached client pool. The # advanced pool will only work under python 2.x Boolean value # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*memcached_servers*] # (Optional) Optionally specify a list of memcached server(s) to use for # caching. If left undefined, tokens will instead be cached in-process. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*region_name*] # (Optional) The region in which the identity server can be found. # Defaults to $::os_service_default. # # [*revocation_cache_time*] # (Optional) Determines the frequency at which the list of revoked tokens is # retrieved from the Identity service (in seconds). A high number of # revocation events combined with a low cache duration may significantly # reduce performance. Only valid for PKI tokens. Updated header flag in SSL opts

Since there are no options at all in SSL - removed all header flags.

subject: Follow up on Update binding:profile for SR-IOV ports
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-28 19:16:17.000000000', 'files': ['nova/network/neutronv2/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/3db49d339e6586c92bfe27a8e8edbd7cee6f864f', 'message': 'Follow up on Update binding:profile for SR-IOV ports

This patch addresses comments from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/242573

commit_message:
Follow up on Update binding:profile for SR-IOV ports

This patch addresses comments from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/242573

- Only load PCI mappings when there is at least one port of type SR-IOV.
- Fixed exception message on neutron port update.

Change-Id: I88586c66a2b2b84a2ff4a5c00857d3da19148268
Partial-bug: #1512880

Change-Id: I9d036fd5d209ccd321fbd28117660494a7bcb74d
Implements: blueprint ironic-networks-support
Co-Authored-By: Hironori Shiina <shiina.hironori@jp.fujitsu.com>
"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2016-07-19 16:42:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/809b7482f95b751f13ef85f87eaf9df91cd7895e', 'message': 'Ironic: enable multitenant networking

This replaces the unused code (due to API versioning) in the ironic
driver's implementation of `network_binding_host_id`, to code that
actually enables the multitenant networking support in ironic.

While building this out, we changed direction and ended with the node's
field being called `network_interface` instead of `network_provider`.
This patch changes this to match, and bumps the ironic API version used
to 1.20, where this feature is introduced.

The old code also assumed ironic would have only two network interfaces,
"neutron" and "none". This became three - "neutron", "flat", and
"noop".[0] "neutron" is the only interface that requires returning None
from `network_binding_host_id`, while the others should match the old
behavior. Change the code to only do this for the neutron network
interface, instead of doing this for anything not called 'flat'.

[0] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/ironic/tree/setup.cfg#n90

Change-Id: I9d036fd5d209ccd321fbd28117660494a7bcb74d
Implements: blueprint ironic-networks-support
Co-Authored-By: Hironori Shiina <shiina.hironori@jp.fujitsu.com>
'}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2016-07-19 19:49:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1df4ce5572cdc554a4da3bba4e331d14f23d18de', 'message': 'Ironic: enable multitenant networking

commit_message:
Ironic: enable multitenant networking

This replaces the unused code (due to API versioning) in the ironic
driver's implementation of `network_binding_host_id`, to code that
actually enables the multitenant networking support in ironic.

While building this out, we changed direction and ended with the node's
field being called `network_interface` instead of `network_provider`.
This patch changes this to match, and bumps the ironic API version used
to 1.20, where this feature is introduced.

The old code also assumed ironic would have only two network interfaces,
"neutron" and "none". This became three - "neutron", "flat", and
"noop".[0] "neutron" is the only interface that requires returning None
from `network_binding_host_id`, while the others should match the old
behavior. Change the code to only do this for the neutron network
interface, instead of doing this for anything not called 'flat'.

[0] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/ironic/tree/setup.cfg#n90

Depends-On: I09a42c8e54d7782c591415e53fccade972ae8bdb
Depends-On: I3c135a4a2c79cfb0b9d63d9d31009330c2abb680
Change-Id: I9d036fd5d209ccd321fbd28117660494a7bcb74d
Implements: blueprint ironic-networks-support
Co-Authored-By: Hironori Shiina <shiina.hironori@jp.fujitsu.com>

commit_message:
Add .gitreview and clean up repo

Update tox.ini to lint unit_tests, clean lint.

Add src/README.md placeholder to prevent inheritence of the
lower layer readme file in the built charm.

Add src/tox.ini and test-requirements for Amulet prep.

Update metadata.yaml for series.

Update tox.ini to minimize and clarify pep8 ignores.

Resolve flake8/pbr test-requirements version range conflict.

Mock apt in unit tests.

Add required tags data in src/metadata.yaml for charm proof.

Use openstack/charms.openstack proper in test-requirements
instead of a user space fork.

Update src/layer.yaml repo value to point to official location
and remove unnecessary options.

Change-Id: I5ca9e6cf9f8f91b3ce0ec3b48cf63535ca37c0f7

commit_message:
Add .gitreview and clean up repo

Add src/README.md placeholder to prevent inheritence of the
lower layer readme file in the built charm.

Add src/tox.ini and test-requirements for Amulet prep.

Update metadata.yaml for series.

Update tox.ini to minimize and clarify pep8 ignores.

Resolve flake8/pbr test-requirements version range conflict.

Remove legacy lint and test targets from Makefile, ensuring
these tests will execute via tox.  Trusty test runners have
no py35 interpreter, and would have failed in running both
py34 and py35 in succession as it was defined.

Update src/layer.yaml repo value to point to official location
and remove unnecessary options.

Change-Id: Ia663fda7761dca6dc08583314f00beedf1db60cc

commit_message:
Convert command line clients to openstackclient

A prerequisite for Newton is to move to openstackclient for interfacing
with the OpenStack services.

Change-Id: I80a10bc1a3a50501306c16e278b960e43e9e9a59
Implements: blueprint openstackclient

commit_message:
Add constraint for positive odd integer

This is needed by tripleo-heat-templates to limit the count of
controller nodes in TripleO deployments.

Change-Id: Ibed2311063a5d835da297238cae4c2f8c9cbd94e

fixes it and also adds an addition test that should have caught it originally.

Change-Id: I7726c949791658a750b9c382107f01e0a112247c
'}]
commit_message:
Properly set SSL cert paths when disabling certs databag

This fixes an oversight in a previous patch when disabling the certs databag. It
would improperly not set the cert paths at all in the apache vhost config. This
fixes it and also adds an addition test that should have caught it originally.

Change-Id: I7726c949791658a750b9c382107f01e0a112247c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-dashboard refs/changes/72/349772/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: context 'set use_data_bag to false' do it 'shows ssl certificate related directives defaults' do node.set['openstack']['dashboard']['ssl']['use_data_bag'] = false [/^\s*SSLEngine on$/, %r{^\s*SSLCertificateFile /etc/ssl/certs/horizon.pem$}, %r{^\s*SSLCertificateKeyFile /etc/ssl/private/horizon.key$}, /^\s*SSLProtocol All -SSLv2 -SSLv3$/].each do |ssl_certificate_directive| expect(chef_run).to render_file(file.name).with_content(ssl_certificate_directive) end expect(chef_run).to_not render_file(file.name) .with_content(/SSLCertificateChainFile/) end context 'set ssl chain' do it 'shows chain directive' do node.set['openstack']['dashboard']['ssl']['use_data_bag'] = false node.set['openstack']['dashboard']['ssl']['chain'] = 'horizon-chain.pem' expect(chef_run).to render_file(file.name) .with_content(%r{^\s*SSLCertificateChainFile /etc/ssl/certs/horizon-chain.pem$}) end end end

commit_message:
Fix issue with snapshot creation in NetApp driver

In case no snapshot_policy is specified in share_type the
"Default" policy is activated. This leads to creation of
useless snapshots that aren't visible to Manila at all.

Change-Id: I7a632ef5e32fa229e0d756611c8539a19d07bb25
Closes-bug: #1609306
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/73/350473/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: thin_provisioned=False, snapshot_policy='none', api_args['snapshot-policy'] = snapshot_policy
deleted_lines: thin_provisioned=False, snapshot_policy=None, if snapshot_policy is not None: api_args['snapshot-policy'] = snapshot_policy

commit_message:
Fix bug with detailed error on node groupe deletion

If node group is used in cluster template and if user is trying
delete this node group, Horizon says unhelpful message about
error. I fix this message.

Change-Id: I670f7843873dad93015a57daafa831389444784d
Closes-bug: 1427277
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-dashboard refs/changes/26/333926/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from horizon import messagesfrom saharaclient.api import base def handle(self, table, request, obj_ids): for obj_id in obj_ids: self.delete(request, obj_id) try: ng = saharaclient.nodegroup_template_get(request, template_id) saharaclient.nodegroup_template_delete(request, template_id) messages.success(request, _("Successfully deleted template %s") % ng.name) except base.APIException as ex: messages.error(request, _("Unable to delete template by reason: %s") % ex.error_message)

Updater script https://review.openstack.org/346119 without this timeout

Change-Id: Icd2b9906c3c3195970f858a4164920b959616352
'}]
commit_message:
Disable "wait_for_external_config" while applying 9.x

Right now 9.x deployment contains 50min timeout created for astute.yaml
modifications but it useless and consumes time when we want to apply
9.x over 9.0 via bootsrtap_admin_node.sh
Updater script https://review.openstack.org/346119 without this timeout
is under development. We can save about 1h of deployment with this
temporary solution before the updater script will be released.

Change-Id: Icd2b9906c3c3195970f858a4164920b959616352
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/42/351042/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # this is temporary solution for disabling 50min timeout; # should be removed when the main script for 9.0->9.x will be merged self.ssh_manager.execute_on_remote( ip=self.ssh_manager.admin_ip, cmd='sed -i ' '"s/wait_for_external_config=yes/wait_for_external_config=no/"' ' /etc/fuel/bootstrap_admin_node.conf') # end of temporary solution

commit_message:
Dell SC: Use Live Volume for replication

Adding support for Dell SC live volume in replication. If
an extra spec is set the driver will attempt to create live
volumes instead of normal replications.

Added to the test coverage.

Minor refactor to failback.

DocImpact
Change-Id: Id0056ec9b9a42005b1f7cb2d8cd5aee208d8015c

commit_message:
Fix restore exception handling

Re-raise exception in restore so that higher
level excption handling can occur. Specifically
rich_queue needs to be closed when an exception
is encountered.

Fixes Bug: #1609094

Change-Id: Ib4d71f85b0c1f14bdd8980b35f23f351df176763

commit_message:
Fix hardcoded static path

Openstack dashboard has defined an option named "WEBROOT"
to specify the location relative to Webserver root.
So we can use it instead of setting hardcoded param.

Closes-Bug: #1597966
Change-Id: I2d33cd7f118608057dc1dabdc7f0acb9e75616e1

Currently, puppet-ceph stable/hammer CI tries to clone Puppet OpenStack
modules using stable/hammer branch but they don't have it, only
puppet-ceph does.
We need to override ZUUL_BRANCH with a fake 'stable/mitaka' for Puppet
OpenStack modules and then checkout 'stable/hammer' for puppet-ceph.

This workaround will allow us to:
* test puppet-ceph/hammer with mitaka modules
* test puppet-ceph/master with newton and beyond modules

Note: for our r10k users, no problem, they use git to checkout the right

commit_message:
Workaround for puppet-ceph zuul-cloning

Currently, puppet-ceph stable/hammer CI tries to clone Puppet OpenStack
modules using stable/hammer branch but they don't have it, only
puppet-ceph does.
We need to override ZUUL_BRANCH with a fake 'stable/mitaka' for Puppet
OpenStack modules and then checkout 'stable/hammer' for puppet-ceph.

This workaround will allow us to:
* test puppet-ceph/hammer with mitaka modules
* test puppet-ceph/master with newton and beyond modules

Note: for our r10k users, no problem, they use git to checkout the right
branch, so they don't have the bug.

Change-Id: I004ee95e6bd97992aeebd08447396e3b8a29e09f
(cherry picked from commit aaac0731aff6197f26fa4be08184cffd602cedd2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration refs/changes/45/350845/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Workaround for puppet-ceph, where we need to checkout # OpenStack modules from stable/mitaka when working on stable/hammer. # Ceph Hammer works with Mitaka and before. # Ceph Jewel works with Newton and beyond. if [[ "$ZUUL_BRANCH" == "stable/hammer" ]]; then ZUUL_BRANCH='stable/mitaka' PUPPET_CEPH_ZUUL_BRANCH='stable/hammer' fi # Clone openstack/puppet-ceph using the real ZUUL_BRANCH. if [ ! -z "$PUPPET_CEPH_ZUUL_BRANCH" ]; then /usr/zuul-env/bin/zuul-cloner -m clonemap.yaml \ --cache-dir /opt/git \ --zuul-ref $ZUUL_REF \ --zuul-branch $PUPPET_CEPH_ZUUL_BRANCH \ --zuul-url $ZUUL_URL \ git://git.openstack.org openstack/puppet-ceph fi

commit_message:
Add project group to role

This patch adds a var used by the repo_build process to determine
which host group to check for members of before building the pip
packages required by this role. This provides the ability to
optimise the repo build process to only building the packages
that are required for an environment.

Depends-On: Idda16b4f382eee57c7469af898859d6d81d4eb30
Change-Id: Iedb4c0c91daa291f881a9fc00c5b8c40bb312ce3

added_lines: # This variable is used by the repo_build process to determine # which host group to check for members of before building the # pip packages required by this role. The value is picked up # by the py_pkgs lookup. swift_role_project_group: swift_all

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-31 22:39:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/efecac58a47545236c32de8c37bdd0e55374ac2f', 'message': "Straddle python-neutronclient 5.0 for testing

for keystone v3 usage. It does this using debtcollector

at runtime but doesn't work with mox since mox stubs the
methods off the Client class, but doesn't pick up and stub
any decorators on those methods. So when our unit tests

We can't pass project_id/project_name in the tests until we
require python-neutronclient>=5.0.0 in global-requirements
and upper-constraints which we can't do if it's going to break

both the 4.2 and 5.0 versions of the client and stubs out

signature depending on which version of python-neutronclient
we're testing with.

Once we land this, we can bump g-r and u-c to use neutronclient
5.0.0 and then once that lands in nova we can remove this hack.

Change-Id: I86bbac3e24bef27396297dfc79eb24c61dbcb6ac
Closes-Bug: #1608258
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-08-01 16:28:29.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/network/test_neutronv2.py', 'nova/network/neutronv2/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a280d2e88c7a732630a5ae00c2c452c6db34cc8b', 'message': "Straddle python-neutronclient 5.0 for testing

any decorators on those methods. So when our unit tests
pass tenant_id kwargs they fail on the moxed_client.

To make the tests work for both neutronclient>5 and <5 we
simply pass the project_id as an arg rather than kwarg
to the show_quota method.

Closes-Bug: #1608258

commit_message:
Straddle python-neutronclient 5.0 for testing

python-neutronclient 5.0 has deprecated the usage of
tenant_id/tenant_name in place of project_id/project_name
for keystone v3 usage. It does this using debtcollector
decorators on the methods with those kwargs. This is fine
at runtime but doesn't work with mox since mox stubs the
methods off the Client class, but doesn't pick up and stub
any decorators on those methods. So when our unit tests
pass tenant_id kwargs they fail on the moxed_client.

To make the tests work for both neutronclient>5 and <5 we
simply pass the project_id as an arg rather than kwarg
to the show_quota method.

Change-Id: I86bbac3e24bef27396297dfc79eb24c61dbcb6ac
Closes-Bug: #1608258
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/97/349297/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # FIXME(mriedem): remove this hack once we require # python-neutronclient>=5.0.0 in global-requirements. from oslo_utils import versionutils import pkg_resources neutronclient_version = ( pkg_resources.get_distribution('python-neutronclient').version) if versionutils.convert_version_to_tuple(neutronclient_version)[0] > 4: # create some alias methods on the moxed_client to use tenant_id orig_show_quota = client.Client.show_quota def show_quota(tenant_id, **_params): return orig_show_quota(tenant_id, **_params) # This has to be done BEFORE moxed_client is created so it picks # up the proper stub for replays. self.stubs.Set(client.Client, 'show_quota', show_quota)

commit_message:
Conf options: updated flags for novnc

Previous patch that addressed consistency in config/novnc.py was merged but
it did not contain updated header flags.

This patch updates header flags for novnc.

Implements blueprint centralize-config-options-newton

Change-Id: I32e90633403748e4f0fca86b936db238c145c501

Add project group to role

This patch adds a var used by the repo_build process to determine
which host group to check for members of before building the pip
packages required by this role. This provides the ability to
optimise the repo build process to only building the packages
that are required for an environment.

Depends-On: Idda16b4f382eee57c7469af898859d6d81d4eb30
Change-Id: Iedb4c0c91daa291f881a9fc00c5b8c40bb312ce3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_magnum refs/changes/68/350968/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This variable is used by the repo_build process to determine # which host group to check for members of before building the # pip packages required by this role. The value is picked up # by the py_pkgs lookup. magnum_role_project_group: magnum_all

commit_message:
api-ref: Split LBaaS API reference into v1 and v2

Previously LBaaS v1 and v2 API have dedicated pages for API reference,
but during RST migration it was merged into one API by accident.
This commit splits them again into dedicated pages.

Note that this commit only sets up separeate API sections.
More clean up of API references will be done later.

Change-Id: I70ef1e3e3b265a4984654c0bd4bedc85b3c6b707
Closes-Bug: #1606381

commit_message:
Add 'fuel2 env remove nodes' command

Release new 'env remove nodes' command in fuel2
to support remove nodes procedure from specific
environment (cluster):

  fuel2 env remove nodes [-h] -e ENV
            (-n NODES [NODES ...] | --nodes-all)

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: 1603440

Change-Id: Ibc14966996ae046307299348f62f758980d31ace
(cherry picked from commit a245303ef51218e705540f56e0d75a5cbb259357)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient refs/changes/84/349984/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def remove_nodes(self, environment_id, nodes=None): """Remove nodes from environment. If nodes are empty list then all nodes will be removed :param environment_id: Id of specific environment (cluster) :type environment_id: int :param nodes: List of node ids that should be removed :type nodes: list """ env = self._entity_wrapper(obj_id=environment_id) if nodes is not None: env.unassign(nodes) else: env.unassign_all()

commit_message:
Delete openstack/common from the exclude list of flake8 in tox

The directory openstack/common was used to keep codes from
oslo-incubator, we have retired oslo-incubator, so don't use
this directory any more.

Change-Id: I3fcbec9fcec6d36c3e8254a809de0ae0b02a4841

added_lines: def __init__(self, container, environments): self.environments = environments envs = [] for path, contents in self.environments.items(): env_path = "user-environments/{}".format(path) full_path = "{}/{}".format(self.container, env_path) swift.put_object(full_path, obj='', contents=contents) envs.append({'path': env_path,}) mistral_env.variables['environments'].extend(envs) env_kwargs = { 'name': mistral_env.name, 'variables': mistral_env.variables } mistral.environments.update(**env_kwargs)
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, container, path, contents): self.path = path self.contents = contents env_path = "user-environments/{}".format(self.path) full_path = "{}/{}".format(self.container, env_path) swift.put_object(full_path, contents=self.contents) mistral_env.variables['environments'].add({ 'path': env_path, })

commit_message:
Fix KeyError: 'THEME' in angular.py

Install murano-dashboard to horizon with master version,
Open the murano-dashboard, give the error:
File "/opt/openstack/horizon/horizon/templatetags/angular.py", line 36, in update_angular_template_hash
    theme = context['THEME'] # current theme being compressed
KeyError: 'THEME'
This patch fix it.

Change-Id: Idceb555e006500874768a60dfb73295a94e461c1
Closes-Bug: #1603307
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/19/342619/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: theme = context.get('THEME', 'default') # current theme being compressed
deleted_lines: theme = context['THEME'] # current theme being compressed

commit_message:
Allow empty list to be passed for a value spec argument

i.e - passing an argument as follows: '... --examples list=true' to
indicate that examples is an empty list.

Change-Id: I2f15fa8314e6bd0689984e924f0b2701d1d699a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/59/347859/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if _value_number > 1 or _list_flag or current_type_str == 'list': current_arg.update({'nargs': '+'}) if _value_number == 0: if _list_flag or current_type_str == 'list': current_arg.update({'nargs': '*'}) elif current_type_str: a bool option (unless 'list=true' specified). Key with two values will be a list option.
deleted_lines: if _value_number == 0 and (current_type_str or _list_flag): if _value_number > 1 or _list_flag or current_type_str == 'list': current_arg.update({'nargs': '+'}) elif _value_number == 0: a bool option. Key with two values will be a list option.

* Add supported version for magnum client

commit_message:
[Spec] Change grouping into deployment graphs table

Grouping in graphs table changed to grouping by type.
This will help user to have explicit vision of which graphs
are related to a particular graph type.
Also, it would be easy for User to download merged graph tasks
from the table.

Related blueprint ui-custom-graph

Change-Id: Ibe10c33af3091fdf493e98b0e3826f148174b3f4

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-11 15:22:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/barbican/commit/0ae7b33a82e898cacd243c3950a6ed6c4ef24abe', 'message': "Add seed random feature to seed HSM RNG

seed of the random number generator (RNG).  The PKCS11 interface provides an
API call for this (C_SeedRandom) so that the caller can seed the RNG.

opensll >= 0.9.5 fails if the RNG is not seeded prior to use which causes (in
this configuration) Barbican to fail when  it needs to use the RNG in the HSM.

commit_message:
Add seed random feature to seed HSM RNG

With the softhsm2 + openssl >= 0.9.5, barbican needs to initialise the random
seed of the random number generator (RNG).  The PKCS11 interface provides an
API call for this (C_SeedRandom) so that the caller can seed the RNG.

opensll >= 0.9.5 fails if the RNG is not seeded prior to use which causes (in
this configuration) Barbican to fail when  it needs to use the RNG in the HSM.

This change adds two configuration options in the [p11_crypto_plugin] section
called 'seed_file' and 'seed_length' which default to empty string and 32
respectively.

If the 'seed_file' configuration file is not configured then this change has no
impact.  If the seed_file is configured, then 'seed_length' bytes/chars are
read from the file and provided to eh C_SeedRandom() api call.

Change-Id: Ib063dfdac90d2a3ea9e4ec3da2d84f6ee5d45b03
Closes-Bug: #1599550
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/37/340437/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.lib.C_SeedRandom.return_value = pkcs11.CKR_OK def test_seed_random(self): rd = "random-data" session = 'session' self.pkcs11._seed_random(session, rd) self.lib.C_SeedRandom.assert_called_once_with( session, mock.ANY, len(rd))

commit_message:
RabbitMQ config rework

RPC configuration now uses transport_url. Notification config
now uses the rabbitmq_telemetry_* vars by default

Role testing is now testing using RabbitMQ with no SSL
for consistency with all other role tests.

Implements: blueprint multi-rabbitmq-clusters
Change-Id: I35664b096ab236e19a3b9dff4bef2ebdeb974039

commit_message:
Enable broader image support

Currently, many values are hard-coded for
cirros images during tempest testing.  In
order to provide support for a wider variety
of system images, some variables have been
renamed to a more generic ``tempest_`` form
instead of the ``cirros_`` form.  Other
variables have been added to make the role
more configurable.

Additionally, many unsupported and deprecated
options still existed in this role.  These
deprecated options centered largely around
tempest.conf.j2.  Of particular note, ari/ami/aki
images have been deprecated by tempest, and
those options have been removed.

The '[boto]' testing section is no longer implemented
in tempest testing, and has been removed.

Change-Id: Ibbe2cc09416963d2326dd760c36c8a985f636734

commit_message:
Add API microversion support

This patch proposes a default header to be injected when sending
requests to a service. The header is added as the support to
the micro-version specification from OpenStack API WorkingGroup [1].

We can use this 'api_version' property to track the micro-versions of
service APIs we support in SDK. Users can optionally specify such an API
version request as preferences in the 'Profile' object.

[1]
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/api-wg/tree/guidelines/microversion_specification.rst

Change-Id: I421232a73de5dcc423a40acb79202a1f12bed430
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/92/343992/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #: The OpenStack API micro-version header. os_api_version = Header("openstack-api-version")

commit_message:
[WIP] Move requirements processing from task to template

In order to improve execution time, the processing of the requirements
list is moved from the tasks to the template.

commit_message:
Revert "Devstack should use a prebuilt ramdisk by default"

This reverts commit 5b752d258a0402abfd7f2511874f42bdf7c77dc1. Due to
devstack-gate only setting IRONIC_BUILD_DEPLOY_RAMDISK=false, this will
prevent IPA source jobs from ever building a new ramdisk.

Change-Id: I3e43c08b7f8e9d41f420b12475c9ce74cb860df9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/89/350789/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: IRONIC_BUILD_DEPLOY_RAMDISK=$(trueorfalse True IRONIC_BUILD_DEPLOY_RAMDISK)

"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-08-01 14:58:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/1bab916285e49b656753ff2070f1ac9ffe8c1295', 'message': "OVN L3 service plugin does not need agent RPC

neutron ExtraRoute_db_mixin class which eventually inherits from
the neutron L3RpcNotifierMixin class. The L3RpcNotifierMixin
inheritance isn't necessary and adds unneeded RPC overhead since

commit_message:
OVN L3 service plugin does not need agent RPC

The OVN L3 service plugin (OVNL3RouterPlugin) inherits from the
neutron ExtraRoute_db_mixin class which eventually inherits from
the neutron L3RpcNotifierMixin class. The L3RpcNotifierMixin
inheritance isn't necessary and adds unneeded RPC overhead since
the OVN L3 service plugin doesn't use an L3 agent.

This patch set fixes the problem by having OVNL3RouterPlugin
inherit from ExtraRoute_dbonly_mixin.

The OVNL3TestCase unit tests were removed because their were
duplicating the OVNL3ExtrarouteTests unit tests.

Depends-On: Id5dd012ffd274314f7d1b39a28525893e0675500
Change-Id: Iad7e7677852e74ed4d4a70e359dbff41f6014e72
Closes-Bug: #1597898
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/59/348559/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.db import l3_db extraroute_db.ExtraRoute_dbonly_mixin): # NOTE(rtheis): Neutron implicitly registers L3 agent callbacks # which aren't needed for OVN. l3_db.unsubscribe_l3_agent_callbacks()

commit_message:
Ensure required interfaces list is correct

When a subset of cinder services is enabled, we don't expect all interfaces
to exist and unexpected errors/warnings to be reported in workload-status.

Closes-Bug: 1606559
(cherry picked from commit 83a23cd56ac204eadaa346ca7d3132be734305d4)
Change-Id: I9d5b6149c847c972d6fb0cfaf697d2885bbbf5c1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-cinder refs/changes/93/350693/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'database': ('shared-db', 'pgsql-db'), 'messaging': ('amqp',), 'identity': ('identity-service',), """Provide the required charm interfaces based on configured roles.""" interfaces = required_interfaces() interfaces.update(get_optional_interfaces()) configs, interfaces,
deleted_lines: 'database': ['shared-db', 'pgsql-db'], 'messaging': ['amqp'], 'identity': ['identity-service'], '''Provide the required charm interfaces based on configured roles.''' required_interfaces = REQUIRED_INTERFACES.copy() required_interfaces.update(get_optional_interfaces()) configs, required_interfaces,

commit_message:
Only build wheels for services which are deployed

The current repo build process builds wheels for all OpenStack services,
regardless of whether they're actually going to be used.

To reduce the repo build time, this patch will only build wheels for
OpenStack services where there is one or more members in the service
inventory group.

An updated set of test vars is included based on a recent stable/mitaka
output of the py_pkgs lookup based on the below-mentioned dependant
patch.

Depends-On: I5e981c818a1da50aa0ae15630655a8dfac4f3db7
Change-Id: Idda16b4f382eee57c7469af898859d6d81d4eb30
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_build refs/changes/12/344912/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Adding idempotency testing to the role func test

Roles should ideally be idempotent so we should test
that they are as part of our automated tests.

Change-Id: I80a6e09b69ed77b4bf2b97eb9e8d6dcd3ea37899
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-apt_package_pinning refs/changes/70/350870/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Idempotency test bash -c 'ansible-playbook -i {toxinidir}/tests/inventory \ -e "rolename={toxinidir}" \ {toxinidir}/tests/test.yml \ | grep -q "changed=0.*failed=0" \ && (echo "Idempotence test: pass" && exit 0) \ || (echo "Idempotence test: fail" && exit 1)'

subject: Fix parameters of assertEqual are misplaced
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-02 06:26:19.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_rootwrap/tests/test_rootwrap.py', 'oslo_rootwrap/tests/test_functional.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/commit/a46b731c8a346d9bbb0c461a64aa3fb970123c86', 'message': "Fix parameters of assertEqual are misplaced

Many assertEqual sentences don't follow assertEqual(expected, actual),
These misplaces have 2 impacts:
1, giving confusing messages when some tests failed.
2, mislead other developers, new test modules may follow these wrong pattern.

This patch fix all of them.

Change-Id: I4adfc98d6eecd5ea117d725775b2476b237212d9
